reviewText: RIFT - a great option for MMO players. Great graphics, beautiful and detailed landscapes. You can customize your character the way you want to by using different souls available within your selected class. For example, take a bit of Pyromancer for offense, a lot of Elementalist for some serious pet capability, and some Chloromancer to heal the party. Rift also has several pre-built options for those who like to get in and play quickly. Beyond all of the systems in the game, the standard things about the game are also very well done. The audio is phenomenal, and the controls are pretty intuitive. Glitches are very infrequent, and minor anyway. Besides, the game is still fairly new so such things are to be expected. Leveling up in this game is not grindy at all. The game frequently keeps you on quests (storyline and otherwise) which level you up as you play the game, rarely (if ever) forcing you to pull off to the side for some time to just level up. The solo-play material is well-handled, as is the group-play material. Gameplay is mostly solid, and the freedom to progress however you wish is definitely a bonus. The quests could benefit from more variety – something Trion should keep in mind for future content updates – and the overarching story is easily lost beneath the endless strings of ‘Collect this!’ and ‘Kill those!’ If you go in expecting total originality, immediate disappointment is sure to follow, but spend some time with the game, and you’ll be impressed with what Trion has to offer. Rift breathes new life into the genre, restoring otherwise tired old concepts and proves success isn’t always built on originality.

reviewText: This is a really good free to play MMO if you're looking to kill time. The best thing about it is that its more or less a WoW clone that doesn't try any ridiculous stuff like a lot of MMOs out there. It sticks to the tried and true formula and that's what I like about it. Notice how the top negative" review is a kid with 230 hours played. He loved the game. reviewText:
From launch through the first year of free-to-play, the game was a joy: beautiful scenery, well-executed dynamic content, and lots to do from pvp to dungeons to fun open world to chasing artifacts.

In the last year, however, it has steadily gone down hill as the publisher has squeezed the screws to harvest more money from the players and the somewhat old engine has become decidedly creaky with poor frame rate, frequent crashes, and very annoying visual bugs. The latter is probably also money related since it appears they have cut developer staff to the bone and they can't afford or choose not to invest further in the core engine.

It is free to play, so you can get a taste of it at little risk but not likely to be a long term game for anyone these days.

reviewText:
Having never played World of Warcraft makes comparing MMO's such as RIFT very difficult to do. As it stands, RIFT delivers an exceptionally well crafted world that's as diverse as it is gorgeous. Lore plays a huge part within RIFT's story, and content is implemented in such a way as to reduce incessant grinding of monsters to close level gaps, content gaps, etc. RIFT's biggest claim to fame currently is the players ability to have near complete control in class building, skill building, and content pathing. Any variety of class is up for grabs, and is subject to change if the player wishes it. The combat system in RIFT is nothing spectacular, but more of the same - such is the case with MMO's. The PvE content is a blast and is (in my humble opinion), what RIFT is really all about. PvP has it's place, but end content rewards just aren't up to par - as of yet (and really, I wouldn't even know). Trion, in the case of RIFT, certainly does not disappoint when it comes to quality content, updates, expansions, as they have been fairly consistent - and free.

In conclusion (speaking as one who's never touched WoW), RIFT both dazzles and amazes in terms of it's free content, the quality of said content, and Trion's willingness to keep the current demographic relatively happy.

EDIT: RIFT has been charging steadily for certain beneficial upgrades like extra skill sets, class sets, and available number of equipable traits (such as foraging, mining, etc). While RIFT still maintains it's free to play philosophy, it has also been funneling players into purchasing certain upgrades such as the ability to swim in water while riding a mount, something which previously was denied players. Most definitely an easy method for a quick buck! Regardless, RIFT is still a much enjoyed title - even with it's slowly (again opinion), developing flaws.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having logged 700+ hours on my old account, I installed it on this one simply to write this review. And I can safely say this is the best F2P MMORPG you will ever play.
Pros:
1) Even though the combat is tab target, it manages to retain aq dynamic feel. All your skills work together in some way so finding the perfect rotation is always interesting. Combat is also incredibly smooth and is really quite enjoyable.
2) The Soul Tree system is perfect and will find a way to fit your play style effortlessly. You can even have custom classes unheard of in most any other game. A mage that doubles as a tank? If you want. A warrior with group healing? Go for it. A cleric with insane DpS? Hell yeah!
3) PvP is AMAZING. I really can't expand on this any more. Try it for yourself. There is very rarely two players using the same build as there are so many possibilities. Endless fun :D
4) The game has a solid storyline that really engages the players. You feel compelled to continue with the main quest line, although that shouldn't deter you from doing as many side quests as you wish. Quests have decent rewards, such as new equipment and a massive pile of cash.
5) Leveling up isn't a huge grind. Granted, there is some grinding to get new equipment or to get PvP gear. But unlike most, it isn't the same quest in the same area over and over again. The quests can be in different areas, and different objectives.
Cons:
1) Dungeons and monsters can get fairly tricky unless you keep on top of your equipment or have some fairly powerful friends. Join a guild for a group of regular party members.
2) You need a hell of a computer to run this game on anything over medium graphics. I currently have an Intel i5, 8 GB of RAM and a Nvidia 640 GT and I can only run it on high at 50-60 FPS. For max you will really need good components.
3) If you don't pay for subscription, it doesn't affect anything a huge amount but you have a few restrictions that are kinda irritating.
i) You can't buy or sell at the auction house.
ii) Pretty small bag space. Probably most annoying.
iii) It will take a LOT of grinding, however, to get a mount.

Overall, a very fun, addictive, and engaging game. Definitly one you should get. It's polished and feels like a paid game. The highest praise a free game could have.

reviewText:
I'm a returning player.  Bought the game in 2011 and quickly leveled a rogue soul to 50 back then, maxed crafting to 300.  At some point, got bored and quit and went on to other games as happens in this industry.  And then it surfaced as a free to play" MMO in my Steam queue.  I'm so glad that it did.  I decided to check it out and I'm hooked all over again.

Just a few bullet points for the returning players / original box set purchases on what you'll find:

- All my characters were on the trial server.  Easily transferred to a "real" server.
- If you purchased a box set back in the day

reviewText: Well, I honestly forgot to write a review for a long time because I was having too much fun with the game. It's a pretty good MMO and the story reminds me of an atheist vs theist world. Atheists had the power of science and theists were told by Gods to destroy this blasphemous technology. This severely weakens the fire power the people had, allowing for an evil force who resembles Satan named Regulos to nearly consume all of Telara. So atheists basically travel back in time 20 years to a Telara where the beginning of Rifts (It's like the Oblivion Gates) start appearing. As for guardians side, you're a theist that works under the Gods and dies defeating Regulos's shade. The Gods notice your power and ressurect you 20 years into the future where Regulos and the Rift holes start appearing because of your power. This is all given to you during the tutorial, which is not the main game and world of telara. Even after the tutorial, there is quite a steep learning curve and the game will continue to provide new hints, you can turn them off if you want, but I don't recommend it until you read them all at least once.\n\nNaturally, if you're in a PvP server, there is more heat between the guardians and defiants. There will be moments where you'll be thinking, Will that guy attack me or not?" And you're waiting for them to respond and see that they think the same thing as well. Definitely adds more tension into the game. PvE enviroment is a lot more casual
date: so the game works well for both casual and hardcore players of the MMO genre.\n\nYou also get to have your own dimension
recommended: which acts like a house and can be decorated. Adds a little bit more to the roleplay if that is your thing."

reviewText: Fantastic game but you will need the expansion which is about £20 or you will not see the later levels. (Many areas are underwater, you'll drown without the expansion.) When you do see the later levels it's wonderful... *UNTIL* you hit max level, then there is a huge gap in gear, with no in game solution, that will prevent you from progressing... unless you spend at least £20 on some store gear. These are not huge sums and perhaps this is not a huge issue, but it feels disingenuous for a 'free to play' game that constantly promotes it's products in game.\n\nOverall, after many hours of fun, you start to feel that the developers have a hand on your wallet just waiting on your word to remove cash. Despite this I still recommend it, as there's plenty of fun to be had here.

reviewText: This game does, in my opinion, have lackluster combat, it is not that thrilling. Starting out, it is very slow, it will take awhile to get to the more fun areas. BUT, once you do get those levels and a decent skill tree, you will find a beautiful gem of a mmo. The developers have taken very good care of this game and not turned it into a forced profit based design. The community is active and lively, between guilds, raid battles, and amazing world boss event battles, this game is worth every minute of time it takes to level into the higher areas. Once you are able to get into the lvl50 areas, you will find a world ripe with rich story, colorful and horrifiing landscapes, and creative npc's.

reviewText:
Pros: Easy to pick up and learn; has many similarities with other popular MMOs. You can change servers and recustomize your character (Excluding gender / race change) without having to pay real money. Changing servers is free, but recustomizing your character is expensive. (In game currency.)

-Only 4 classes, but many different souls (Specializations) to choose from, and can have 3 souls active at a time. You can play your character however you want to.

-PvP is fun in my opinion. Kind of reminds me of Unreal Tournament / Quake in the sense that it has an announcer that will announce events. First Blood" "Killing Spree" "Unstoppable" etc. I found that pretty cool.

-Has an in-game video recorder

you aren't too limited in that regard.

reviewText: This game is AWESOME. It's just like WoW, except the classing and skill trees are much more in depth. The way it works are that there are 4 classes, and each class has 5 sub set classes(4 without dlc), effectively making 20 classes(16 without dlc). Then the skill trees(soul trees). You can click on the base of any one of the three soul trees and swap it with like, another 5 possibilities, effectively making 8 skill trees available to your class, and endless combinations of 3. One issue I have so far is that I appear not to be able to sell anything to vendors that isn't gray. This is rather annoying and doesn't make sense. I could understand if it was soulbound, but they aren't. There needs to be a sell section.

reviewText: I have a pet bunny in this game, Martha, and I have an item (S'mores) that makes me look like a bunny. So on my hotbar I have this macro that casts all my various buffs and armors that I'll hit every so often to make sure they're refreshed and active at all times. First command in the macro - use S'mores. Every time the effect of my S'mores is about to run out I just hit the key for my macro, happens to be 2, and the effect is refreshed. I am a bunny FOREVER. Infinibunny.\n\nSo I go fight mobs and stuff, blah blah blah, and it's funny because people will actually stop and look and act confused because here's this bunny being followed by another bunny and it's hurling fireballs at people (I'm a Pyromancer/Elementalist thingy and yes, you can use all your abilities WHILE BEING A BUNNY). My character's name is even Bunnychu (it had been just Bunny" but I had to change it when I transferred servers
date:
sad :/) so I think this adds to the effect. The whole thing is marvelous.

My human form is cool too because I have purple pigtail braids and I dye all my clothes purple (I'm very particular about my outfits and which clothing I want to be shown wearing) so I look pretty cute but who doesn't want to be an INFINIBUNNY that THROWS FIREBALLS and CONFUSES PEOPLE?

This game is fantastic."

reviewText:
This is an awesome MMORPG that is slightly different then most. For example there are 4 classes and each class has 8 different skill trees(Reffered to as Soul Trees) for different play styles and each skill/soul tree is like a subclass.
CLERIC SUBCLASSES:

CABALIST- The Cabalist is an offensive Cleric who draws on powers that others fear. Using ritual and sigil to call forth seeping death and suffocating water, he devastates the battlefield with powerful attacks that catch all of his enemies in his grip
DRUID- Druids are melee Clerics who forge bonds with Fae creatures, strengthening their bodies, minds, and spirits by drawing upon the magical energies of their companions.
INQUISITOR- The Inquisitor is a cleric who no longer follows the doctrines of life or death alone; instead, they stand between these forces demanding purity from both. An Inquisitor passes judgment on those who are worthy, and damns those who are corrupt.
JUSTICAR- Justicars are healing clerics who fight shoulder-to-shoulder with their allies in close combat. Conviction builds with each swing of their weapon, bolstering nearby comrades and powering the Justicar’s potent healing magic.
PURIFIER- These Clerics draw upon a pact with their long-dead ancestors as the source of their offensive power. While Purifiers wreathe their allies in flames, they can unleash a spirit vanguard to visit wrath upon their foes.
SENTINEL- The Sentinel brings the blessings of light to all who do the will of the gods. Capable of healing many wounded at one time, Sentinels bolster their allies and protect themselves with divine wrath.
SHAMAN- The Shaman binds the power of the icy north to his very being, wreathing himself in pure elemental force. This power augments a Shaman’s attacks, making him a powerful melee combatant, and provides shields and reactive healing.
WARDEN- Echoing the soothing ebb and flow of the tides, Wardens specialize in slow healing that escalates over time, making them ideal for prolonged fights that would exhaust most healers.
MAGE SUBCLASSES:

ARCHON- Archons are support specialists who steal their opponents’ strength and convert that raw energy into beneficial magic. These mages bolster their allies and unleash potent kinetic blasts, quickly turning the tide of battle.
CHLOROMANCER- The Chloromancer is a healing specialist who draws on the vital energies of plants and nature to find a balance between life and death. They harness these energies into a devastating force, or recycle destructive magic to heal their allies.
DONINATOR- The Dominator is a support Mage who terrorizes opponents, leaving them unable or unwilling to act. Those who muster the courage to assault a Dominator will find themselves at the mercy of arcane shields that turn the fury of their own blows against them.
ELEMENTALIST- Elementalists are mages who specialize in manipulating and controlling the raw energies of the planes. Through fierce discipline and strict study, these mages dedicate themselves to commanding the harshest and most chaotic forces known to exist.
NECROMANCER- Necromancers are damage dealers who synergize with their pets. The majority of a Necromancer’s damage comes from a fully supported and buffed pet. In an emergency, Necromancers can also serve as secondary healers by sacrificing their own health to their allies.
PYROMANCER- Pyromancers are destructive mages whose sole focus is the mastery of fire, from launching massive incinerating blasts, to trapping their opponents behind a smoldering wall of flame. No other Ascended can match the sheer destruction at the Pyromancer’s fingertips.
STORMCALLER- Stormcallers are mages who channel the raw fury of the wind and water to command the battlefield, chilling their opponents to the bone or stopping their hearts with electric shock.
WARLOCK- Consummate practitioners of the dark arts, Warlocks embrace the grim forces of entropy and death. Protected within a cloak of shadows, they lurk on the edges of the conflict, as their deadly energies inevitably consume all that stand in their way.
ROUGE SUBCLASSES:

ASSASSIN- Masters of subtlety and subterfuge, an Assassin’s ability to walk in the shadows allows them to bypass obstacles and launch devastating surprise attacks. A rare few survive the initial assault, only to succumb to virulent poisons.
BARD- Singing the songs of battle and playing heart-stirring cadences, Bards embolden their allies and cripple their enemies through rhythm and rhyme.
BLADEDANCER- Blade Dancers are masters of wielding edged weapons. They specialize in ritualized combat movements that are lightning fast. Blade Dancers can overwhelm even an accomplished opponent's defenses, setting them up for a devastating coup de grace.
MARKSMEN- Marksmen are offensive sharpshooters trained to thin enemy ranks with ruthless efficiency. They combine swift hit-and-run attacks with devastating volleys, endlessly harassing targets, sowing the battlefield with dead and crippled foes.
NIGHTBLADE- Possessing deadly agility and mastery of the blade, the Nightblade can also draw upon the planar magics of fire and death to deal doom in a variety of ways. Favoring light armor, their ability to stalk and quickly eliminate their adversaries means the unfortunate quarry rarely has the chance to defend, let alone counterattack.
RANGER- Rangers are consummate hunters who know the strengths and weaknesses of every beast, taming animal companions to augment their considerable prowess in ranged combat. This synergy between bow and beast allows Rangers to handily overcome the most daunting obstacles.
RIFSTALKER- The Riftstalker is a defensive specialist who bends the planes to enhance his constitution and shift in and out of the physical dimension. These highly skilled and survivable combatants keep their opponents’ focus while easily evading incoming blows.
SABOTEUR- The Saboteur is a cunning Rogue who uses explosives and other incendiaries to cripple opponents and control the battlefield. With proper preparation, a Saboteur can destroy enemies without ever giving them a chance to join battle.
WARRIOR SUBCLASSES:

BEASTMASTER- This Warrior's journey begins by bonding to a spirit companion. The spirit beast fights beside the Beastmaster with speed and strength and sees him through his darkest trials.
CHAMPION- Champions are powerful Warriors who excel at melee combat. Wielding massive two-handed weapons, these battle-tested fighters find few equals in one-on-one battle. Champions strive to become one with their blade, constantly honing their fighting skills to win glory through warfare.
PALADIN- Righteous defenders of the weak, Paladins use heavy shields and divine blessings to stand as a bulwark against their foes. The Paladin’s large shield not only offers protection, but affords many opportunities to launch devastating counters in close combat.
PARAGON- The Paragon moves like a furious storm, never giving his enemy time to regroup. A master of dual-wielding, he uses parries and disciplined forms to build up power attacks and stay out of danger.
REAVER- Reavers are warriors who combine the art of combat with the entropic energies of death. The slightest touch of their weapon can spread disease, incite madness, and death to those unlucky enough to face them.
RIFTBLADE- Riftblades are Warriors who learn to enhance their attacks with elemental magic, allowing them to cast bolts of force across the battlefield and strike with boundless energies.
VOIDNIGHT- The Void Knight is a defensive Warrior who uses eldritch techniques to counter magic-wielding foes. Spells that would bring another Warrior low are shaken off by a Void Knight, reflected back at the caster, or stored in pacts the Void Knight can unleash to devastating effect.
WARLORD-A Warlord’s commanding presence expresses itself in auras that inspire her comrades to victory and cow her enemies into submission, allowing her to control the field of battle.
8.5/10 Great!

reviewText:
This game is Riftastic.

Gamplay: 8.5 of 10
Graphics: 8.5 of 10
Sound/Atmosphere:  9 of 10
Community: 7 of 10
End Game/Replay Value: 9 of 10

Don't let my play time fool you, I have 3 characters lvl 60 and 1 with top gear (I just reinstalled my game on steam).

I don't know what made me play Rift at first.

Warhammer Online was dying and I found myselt not having as much time for MMORPGs.

I tried SWTOR my first F2P, it was okay but the end game didn't grab me.

So as a last attempt I switched over to RIFT. Tired of leveling up and going through the questing stuff I mainly stuck to the pvp.

After a day or so of learning the soul system I realized that you can customize your character in an incredible amout of ways! You get four starting classes: Warrior, Rogue, Cleric, Mage. but you can customize them anyway you want, for example: tired of healing on your cleric and want to be a Tank instead? Just once flick of a button and all your skills (plus quickbars) change to reflect your role change.

Really refreshing, I use the role change constantly and I see others do so as well.

The game is kinda your standard MMORPG with quests and leveling, the story is pretty cool as well as the dungeons and bosses. They are hard, but not too hard.

Lots of floating rocks and invading monsters to kill.

Twoards the end of the game you join conquest, a massive free for all capture the node type game. The more you play it the more perks you earn, yet if you stop playing you will lose those perks as they degrade overtime.

I play on the PVP server and it is active, people tell me that the other servers are doing good as well.

The servers allow for cross queuing, which cuts down drastically on wait times for dungeons and pvp warfronts.

The games difficulty revolves around mastering the soul system, you get 3 souls to chose from and a limited amount of abilities from each soul.

Finding the right combination can be the difference of being OP and average.

My advice: Don't just listen to people in-game/forums, test out your own abilities and do your own trial and error.

For instance, people told me not to make a rouge/ranger as they are useless" well that just motivated me to make one even more.

Granted my ranger isn't powerful one on one
date:
but in a group or duing a Warfront I can easily get top dps and I notice the support my character brings.

Cons:

After playing Warhammer Online I was spoiled with a good tank class that mattered (in pvp and pve). Since then no other game can seem to get it right.

Which mean's RIFT is basically a game of DPS and Healer (maybe support if you know how to do it properly).

This makes the game a tad bit bland but never boring.

Over Powered (OP) Classes - (happens in every game) but be prepared to see an over abunence of Mage:Pyro
hoursPlayed:
Rogue:Assassin.

F2P - I understand Trion has to make money somehow but they do charge you for extra bag space. Granted I never needed it but if you want to craft or do something which requires lot of bag/vault space be prepared to fork over money.

It's not pay to win (P2W)
voteText: you don't need to pay to be the best in the game. Paying just really helps you get more powerful in a shorter amount of time. reviewText:
If you miss WoW but don't have the time to dedicate to a subscription based game this is a great alternative. The quests are your standard kill these or collect this. However, Rift features many other things to do practically right from the start.

Closing rifts - Randomly spawning rifts that have several waves of mobs that must be defeated, each a little stronger. Best done with a group but can be soloed. Some good xp and loot from doing these.

Instant Adventures (starting at level 10 I believe) - Go into an instant adventure and get put into a group all working towards completing the different quests culminating in a big boss that is best done with a raid. Great for taking a break from quest grinding and earning some good xp, in-game money, and loot.

I have not tried PVP yet but I have heard it is good.

The part I appreciated the most is that as soon as you have the coin you can buy a mount. Big relief not to have to run everywhere.

The professions are your standard gather/crafting and need to be leveled and new recipes purchased.

This is a free to play game and quite honestly one can play and not have to pay anything. However, until a real money purchase is made the Auction House is locked to sales and the amount of coin held on a character is capped. I believe a small purchase of only $5 will unlock these but since I have yet to purchase anything I'm not sure. This is not a pay to win type of game. You can get boosts, open up bag and character slots, purchase vanity items and mounts but nothing looks like it will give you an edge over free players.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Rift has what most games these days have lost. It provides an enjoyable experience rather than an endless grind to the next level. reviewText: The game starts out a little slow but once you hit level 10 it gets really interesting. It has a great storyline and the RIFTS are really fun along with all the other events that happen while you play. Customization of your character is outstanding, you can build it however you want or follow a preset build path which is helpful for new players. voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Minus ~5 bucks for the freemium membership( to sell in the AH, and maybe a bag slot) this game is completely f2p. I chose to buy the expansion pack but it really isn't needed at all( 4 extra talent trees, one for each class). as far as that buffing my mage it was pretty miniscule. (basically 5 points in the tree only ... difference was 5% damage or 10% spell power). I mained restoration druid in wow and chlormancer mage is pretty much the same deal.

I'm also more of a pvp player and you can level up strictly from pvp which is a huge plus; by the time you hit max level you will be able to afford 4-5 pieces of favor gear and will have atleast 50 prestige level. unfortunately thats where it falls off and starts becoming alittle repeatative. Forced Conquest kinda sucks and it seems to be fairly random when they start as it can be over an hour wait to get into one.

Some other complaints are the lack of end game content; also seperation of gear from PVE and PVP; you will need 2 sets at high level.. and even more if you play different roles. Conquest has TERRIBLE FPS(im talking 10-15 at lowest settings if that) and i would consider this to be a mid-high end pc. I5 3770K 16gb ram. sapphire radeon hd7870. granted it is 40v40v40 so there is alot going on.

otherthan conquest it runs maxxed out on ultra at 60+ frames and looks pretty good in my opinion.

at the end of the day; it was a good experience and definately worth the ~25 dollars I put into it. (you can easily spend zero)

reviewText:
This is a really great mmo. It has all the trappings of familiar mmos, yet brings its own distinctive flavor to the table. Rift has a wonderful storyline and is great for an RPer, because they'll be able to add their own story easily into the lore. Rift also has a variety of ways to level up characters without become too boring and repetitive. Like many other mmos, yes there is a rep grind to get the better gear, but there are many ways to actually do the grind.

Rift recently went free to play and has an honest f2p system. The game isn't p2win at all. F2players are able to play with minimal difference from the subscribers. If you're looking for a challenge, this is definitely something to try.

Pros:

1. Raids, instances, pvp, instant adventures. Chronicles: 1-2 people instances.
2. Collections to search for during the leveling process.
3. Dimensions: aka player housing!
4. Really robust dimension decorating system.
5. Great crafting system.
6. Easy to understand leveling system.
7. Myriad of classes and class trees.
8. Great community
9. 6 races to choose from
10. Frequent updates
11. Fully customizable ui
12. Minmal addons required
13. The game is geographically HUGE.

Cons:
1. talent trees are a little tricky at first, but luckily the game comes with premade builds
2. Aoe can be a bit hard to see at first, adjust graphics accordingly.
3. Will need a bit of a higher end computer to play at full glorious detail.
4. This is one of those games where having a supportive guild can really make or break it for you.
5. Instances/heroic instances are accessable to all, however raids are usually ran by guilds.
6. It can be a bit much to learn at first.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I spent a lot of time playing WoW and I paid a lot of money to have a toon run around in their substandard world. Rift has a lot of angles that appeal to the different tastes of different players.  If you want to craft, you can, if you want to quest, you can, dungeons, PvP, instant quests, artifacts... there is a lot to this game.\n\nThe tl;dr takeaway is that it is free and you'll find it is a pretty good investment of your time.

reviewText:
Built for players who liked World of Warcraft's layout, but wanted something a little more individual. What Rift has going for it is it's familiar, yet you never feel like a mundane, simple mortal or weakling: from the very start you're an ascended, and you feel powerful.

The skills are colorful and visually appealing, and feel satisfying. Your class is determined by 3 souls (similar to WoW's specializations), only you can mix and match any 3 out of 8 that you can unlock total (plus there's a PvP soul you can also unlock.) In short, this gives you acces to a lot of skills and the freedom to pick and choose your most significant ones (much like in Guild Wars) .

Leveling is quick. Quests are clustered together and never take long (a slight grind that is far faster than it ever was in WoW), yet in addition Rifts will pop up, sometimes even invasions, which players are eager to pop up and seal off due to the large amounts of rewards and XP.

Great MMO.

There are 4 classes Warrior Rogue Mage and Cleric. When I saw this though, I thought aww thats not enough. But what I didn't know was that there are these subclasses called Souls that can further increase and specify the gameplay that you want. I have played for about 2 days and I am already level 23. reviewText:
This is an awesome MMORPG that is slightly different then most. For example there are 4 classes and each class has 8 different skill trees(Reffered to as Soul Trees) for different play styles and each skill/soul tree is like a subclass.
CLERIC SUBCLASSES:

CABALIST- The Cabalist is an offensive Cleric who draws on powers that others fear. Using ritual and sigil to call forth seeping death and suffocating water, he devastates the battlefield with powerful attacks that catch all of his enemies in his grip
DRUID- Druids are melee Clerics who forge bonds with Fae creatures, strengthening their bodies, minds, and spirits by drawing upon the magical energies of their companions.
INQUISITOR- The Inquisitor is a cleric who no longer follows the doctrines of life or death alone; instead, they stand between these forces demanding purity from both. An Inquisitor passes judgment on those who are worthy, and damns those who are corrupt.
JUSTICAR- Justicars are healing clerics who fight shoulder-to-shoulder with their allies in close combat. Conviction builds with each swing of their weapon, bolstering nearby comrades and powering the Justicar’s potent healing magic.
PURIFIER- These Clerics draw upon a pact with their long-dead ancestors as the source of their offensive power. While Purifiers wreathe their allies in flames, they can unleash a spirit vanguard to visit wrath upon their foes.
SENTINEL- The Sentinel brings the blessings of light to all who do the will of the gods. Capable of healing many wounded at one time, Sentinels bolster their allies and protect themselves with divine wrath.
SHAMAN- The Shaman binds the power of the icy north to his very being, wreathing himself in pure elemental force. This power augments a Shaman’s attacks, making him a powerful melee combatant, and provides shields and reactive healing.
WARDEN- Echoing the soothing ebb and flow of the tides, Wardens specialize in slow healing that escalates over time, making them ideal for prolonged fights that would exhaust most healers.
MAGE SUBCLASSES:

ARCHON- Archons are support specialists who steal their opponents’ strength and convert that raw energy into beneficial magic. These mages bolster their allies and unleash potent kinetic blasts, quickly turning the tide of battle.
CHLOROMANCER- The Chloromancer is a healing specialist who draws on the vital energies of plants and nature to find a balance between life and death. They harness these energies into a devastating force, or recycle destructive magic to heal their allies.
DONINATOR- The Dominator is a support Mage who terrorizes opponents, leaving them unable or unwilling to act. Those who muster the courage to assault a Dominator will find themselves at the mercy of arcane shields that turn the fury of their own blows against them.
ELEMENTALIST- Elementalists are mages who specialize in manipulating and controlling the raw energies of the planes. Through fierce discipline and strict study, these mages dedicate themselves to commanding the harshest and most chaotic forces known to exist.
NECROMANCER- Necromancers are damage dealers who synergize with their pets. The majority of a Necromancer’s damage comes from a fully supported and buffed pet. In an emergency, Necromancers can also serve as secondary healers by sacrificing their own health to their allies.
PYROMANCER- Pyromancers are destructive mages whose sole focus is the mastery of fire, from launching massive incinerating blasts, to trapping their opponents behind a smoldering wall of flame. No other Ascended can match the sheer destruction at the Pyromancer’s fingertips.
STORMCALLER- Stormcallers are mages who channel the raw fury of the wind and water to command the battlefield, chilling their opponents to the bone or stopping their hearts with electric shock.
WARLOCK- Consummate practitioners of the dark arts, Warlocks embrace the grim forces of entropy and death. Protected within a cloak of shadows, they lurk on the edges of the conflict, as their deadly energies inevitably consume all that stand in their way.
ROUGE SUBCLASSES:

ASSASSIN- Masters of subtlety and subterfuge, an Assassin’s ability to walk in the shadows allows them to bypass obstacles and launch devastating surprise attacks. A rare few survive the initial assault, only to succumb to virulent poisons.
BARD- Singing the songs of battle and playing heart-stirring cadences, Bards embolden their allies and cripple their enemies through rhythm and rhyme.
BLADEDANCER- Blade Dancers are masters of wielding edged weapons. They specialize in ritualized combat movements that are lightning fast. Blade Dancers can overwhelm even an accomplished opponent's defenses, setting them up for a devastating coup de grace.
MARKSMEN- Marksmen are offensive sharpshooters trained to thin enemy ranks with ruthless efficiency. They combine swift hit-and-run attacks with devastating volleys, endlessly harassing targets, sowing the battlefield with dead and crippled foes.
NIGHTBLADE- Possessing deadly agility and mastery of the blade, the Nightblade can also draw upon the planar magics of fire and death to deal doom in a variety of ways. Favoring light armor, their ability to stalk and quickly eliminate their adversaries means the unfortunate quarry rarely has the chance to defend, let alone counterattack.
RANGER- Rangers are consummate hunters who know the strengths and weaknesses of every beast, taming animal companions to augment their considerable prowess in ranged combat. This synergy between bow and beast allows Rangers to handily overcome the most daunting obstacles.
RIFSTALKER- The Riftstalker is a defensive specialist who bends the planes to enhance his constitution and shift in and out of the physical dimension. These highly skilled and survivable combatants keep their opponents’ focus while easily evading incoming blows.
SABOTEUR- The Saboteur is a cunning Rogue who uses explosives and other incendiaries to cripple opponents and control the battlefield. With proper preparation, a Saboteur can destroy enemies without ever giving them a chance to join battle.
WARRIOR SUBCLASSES:

BEASTMASTER- This Warrior's journey begins by bonding to a spirit companion. The spirit beast fights beside the Beastmaster with speed and strength and sees him through his darkest trials.
CHAMPION- Champions are powerful Warriors who excel at melee combat. Wielding massive two-handed weapons, these battle-tested fighters find few equals in one-on-one battle. Champions strive to become one with their blade, constantly honing their fighting skills to win glory through warfare.
PALADIN- Righteous defenders of the weak, Paladins use heavy shields and divine blessings to stand as a bulwark against their foes. The Paladin’s large shield not only offers protection, but affords many opportunities to launch devastating counters in close combat.
PARAGON- The Paragon moves like a furious storm, never giving his enemy time to regroup. A master of dual-wielding, he uses parries and disciplined forms to build up power attacks and stay out of danger.
REAVER- Reavers are warriors who combine the art of combat with the entropic energies of death. The slightest touch of their weapon can spread disease, incite madness, and death to those unlucky enough to face them.
RIFTBLADE- Riftblades are Warriors who learn to enhance their attacks with elemental magic, allowing them to cast bolts of force across the battlefield and strike with boundless energies.
VOIDNIGHT- The Void Knight is a defensive Warrior who uses eldritch techniques to counter magic-wielding foes. Spells that would bring another Warrior low are shaken off by a Void Knight, reflected back at the caster, or stored in pacts the Void Knight can unleash to devastating effect.
WARLORD-A Warlord’s commanding presence expresses itself in auras that inspire her comrades to victory and cow her enemies into submission, allowing her to control the field of battle.
8.5/10 Great!

reviewText:
What is RIFT?  Pretty much a FTP WoW, but without some of the annoying crap.  Like playing the MMOs, but also like to do a lot of soloing?  This is for you.  I personally did not care for WoW's dungeons due to the pettiness.  Here, RIFT forces some group play via randomly (and constantly) spawning Rifts on the main board.  Join group, close Rifts, kill mega-boss, collect loot.  No gripping, whining or trolling. Then go back your soloing.

For those enjoying dungeon crawls/raids and are not anti-social, the dungeons are fun and sprawling.  The final bosses have unique game mechanics and good loot drop.  The dividing is based on the roll-need-greed system.

Trade-chat.  It is what it is.

Is it really FTP?  Yes.  You can buy cosmetics, pets and unique rides, but most of these can also be bought for platinum.  The only thing I am disappointed about is that you need to buy into the Auction House to sell items, or buy REX off the auction house to open it up.  Really though, it's only $5 (USD), ordyou can earn the plat and buy REX, which with some creative mat gathering won't take forever.

TL;DR:  Free except auction house.  solo-friendly.

voteText:
Stealth and Support spec. Resetting these roles is also extremely cheap.

Endgame gear uses synergy crystals that have different stats based on a main soul. So you do not need lots of different gear sets. You just swap the synergy crystal.

reviewText:
Updated Review for Nightmare Tide ~3.4
Note, i play this MMO all the time, I just don't normally log in through steam so my hours show lower than they are.

Positive:
- 100% free content
- New content at a decent pace
- Lots of activity for Nonraiders
Artifact hunting, Dimensions, chronicles, wardrobes, pvp....etc
- Lots of Lore contained ingame.
- Lots of Lore available for nonraiders
- Amazing Wardrobe system
- Massive Zone Events
- Multiple Leveling paths
- Sidekick/Mentor system
- Amazing Soul/Talent System
- Each class plays roles differently and breaks archetypes (mage tank is a thing!)
- Amazing Scenary
- Free daily gift
- The best gear is unavailable in the store! so 0% p2w
- Funny voiceovers (ymmv)

Negative
- There is a strong pay for convenience
Bag slots, Earring slots, Water Attunement Minions....
- Nonoptimal CPU/GPU usage
- Buggy Patches, normally get fixed fast though
- Semi-slow ticket response
- there's now an annoying store popup for the first daily log in, but one click/esc it's gone.

Recommended Purchases if you like the game:
-Original/Storm Legion Box code
unlocks bag slots, and extra toon slots and SL box unlocks SL souls
-SL/Dream souls
-Nightmare tide collector
Unlocks earrings and planeswalker:water, which is a grind ingame otherwise
-Power Pack
unlocks an amphibious mount and leveling cape
-Primalist Class - eh, Maybe. it's a different playstyle for sure
Test it before any purchases though, you don't need to purchase anything to do raiding/pvp/dungeons etc. all the content is free.

This is a good MMO. I indulged in the new primalist class and slow leveled through old zones and was surprised at the amount of Lore present. Also defiant > guardian for lore.

reviewText: I started playing Rift when it was pay-to-play and leveled up quickly. Too quickly, which killed it for me as I was able to try different builds with very little effort. I decided to pursue other games on the market till the free-to-play came on the market, and I came back to give the game another shot.\nLeveling is still easy, and classes are either pro or gimp, but I still find it amusing to play. Ultimately my favorite aspect of the game is the PvE, and the idea of the rifts bringing people together to play as a team. Really love that community aspect of the game, as it aids in higher level PvP.\nIf you want a free game that you can sink 300+ hours into without feeling drained, make a few friends, and kill a few baddies, then Rift is the game for you!

reviewText:
I have played A LOT of MMO's, but as far as free to play ones go, this has to be the best.

What I like about it:

-Not pay to win, just pay for cosmetics or to grind less
-great PvP system
-Good integration of Mounts and Pets
-Personal dimensions / Guild dimensions
- The rifts themselves are badass, for anyone who has played oblivion, it is comparable to that.
-Customizable skill trees
-Good community
- Dungeons, raids and 2 player instances
- Mentor system if you want to help your friend who is a lower level
-TONS of content and new things to explore

reviewText:
Pros: Easy to pick up and learn; has many similarities with other popular MMOs. You can change servers and recustomize your character (Excluding gender / race change) without having to pay real money. Changing servers is free, but recustomizing your character is expensive. (In game currency.)

-Only 4 classes, but many different souls (Specializations) to choose from, and can have 3 souls active at a time. You can play your character however you want to.

-PvP is fun in my opinion. Kind of reminds me of Unreal Tournament / Quake in the sense that it has an announcer that will announce events. First Blood" "Killing Spree" "Unstoppable" etc. I found that pretty cool.

-Has an in-game video recorder
date: which is a first for MMOs. However
recommended: it does not record sound last I checked. Not for me anyway.\n\n-UI Customization is good
hoursPlayed:
you aren't too limited in that regard.

-Average playerbase is usually friendly and helpful.

-Can be played even on very bad computers. (Obviously your experience may not be ideal
voteText: but you should generally be able to play the game.)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCons: Only 6 races. 3 per faction. 4 of which are literally copy
helpfulPercent: pasted
votesHelpful:
and reskinned. There are only 2 unique races. Bahmi and Dwarves.

-Game is not incredibly populated.

-Only a few servers that I know of that have a decent playerbase
votesTotal: the rest are dead. For lack of a better word
votesFunny: the questing is
commentsCount: what I'd call
column16: corridor questing. There aren't multiple same-level zones to choose from
column17:
should you decide you don't want to play in a certain. You have to level in a line of questing areas. No choice.

(No more cons come to mind at the moment.)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
There's more that can be said
column18: but overall I enjoyed the game. It's certainly not bad by any means. It'd be better if it was more popular and had at least 1 more race for each faction that wasn't copy / pasted. If you get this game
column19: it's certainly not a bad idea to bring a friend. I'd give this game a 7/10. It is subscription based. $15 per month. With new accounts
column20: when you subscribe and set up a payment plan
column21: your first month is free. (Your monthly billing will begin on the second month.)"

reviewText: At first I thought this game was a cheap WoW knock off, and thought badly of it because of a few people I heard saying it was bad... There's so much to do: A decent PvP, amazing PvE, Rift Hunts, 3 professions, Quest, Dungeon, Explore and it's all free, with the option to pay for extras, IT'S NOT PAY2WIN!!!! you buy outfits, bonus vials, mounts, and many other things including a way to sell Credits for In-game currency. The only thing I wish was in this game, is flying mounts. But definitely a great game for anyone who enjoys RPG.

reviewText: It has been a long time since I've burned my time in an MMO. I'm a player of some of the classics: Dark Age of Camelot (remember that one?), a year or so of World of Warcraft, another year of EQ2, and several years of LOTRO. Finally, I couldn't resist the bug anymore and decided to check out Rift since it was F2P. I was not disappointed. The game pushed the art of game designs beyond what I had experienced in some very rewarding ways:\n\n1. Design your own player classes. Yes, you have to choose the overall categories of Warrior, Rogue, Cleric or Mage, but out of the 9 skill trees available for each one, you can pick whichever 3 you wish. For very small prices, you can also assign different roles" to your character
date: meaning that you can have one build set up for solo
hoursPlayed: and yet another for Raids. Very special! I am an inveterate tinkerer. I love tinkering with Rift class design.\n\n2. Free form player homes. In Rift
voteText: player homes are called dimensions. Players may have access to many dimesions of their own

reviewText: What can I say about RIFT?  I'll keep this simple.  RIFT is my all-time favorite MMORPG.  It doesn't take the genre in a whole new direction.  What it does do, though (and quite successfully, I might add), is offer a stunning and exciting take on the classic MMO formula.  Classes have seeminly endless levels of customization, encouraging players to try different combinations of skill trees called Souls to build the perfect character for their play style.  This, along with the living world invasion events, where dozens of players hold off hundreds of enemies in an active zone event, comes together for an awesome MMORPG experience.  Sick of whiny twelve year olds playing World of Pandacraft?  Play RIFT.  It has an awesome community of gamers who take the experience seriously, and offer up endless help to those who need it.  It is a welcome challenge, too, offering more than just an endless chain of Kill 10 wolves" quests (though those are there

reviewText: This game is a must play even if you don't like MMORPG's. The controls will be very awkward for most when you first start but you can completely change the key bindings and I would always be happy to make it much easier for you. This game allows you to really get involved with what goes on with your character. You can change everything about them and how they play against others. There is pvp where you test your skills against other players with your unique class or you can join a group and run through dungeons where you fight harder mobs and bosses. If you want to level other ways there is also the traditional questing. This is where you do something for someone in the game in exchange for experience which helps you level up. The max level is 60 and it is a very long journey. Everytime that you level up you get a little stronger and the end game level 60 content is worth the wait. So if you are considering playing this game then my advice would be yes and if you ever need help please ask about anything involving the game.

reviewText:
Gameplay - similar to most other MMO's in the WoW vein, but the enemies, environments, dungeons, etc seem to keep things fresher than in some other MMO's.  I do like the way that rift's rip into a world and can cause huge fights in the middle of nowhere if no one closes them...full blown bosses can drop out of a rift.  I've seen 20+ people fighting a boss + enemies that fell out of a rift.  There is also tons of crafting, and there are tons of collectables, etc.  I'd say by about level 15 to 20 you should be seeing some pretty big rifts appearing out of nowhere.  This is very different from games like WoW.  If the rift is allowed to grow, big, big enemies can eventually come out of it.  Basically, rifts are giant holes that appear and start spewing enemies.  If no one closes the rift, then the rift levels up and even harder enemies come out of it.  Eventually, if left unchecked, the enemies will attack a settlement or other players.  They also cause land/environment deformations, and there are several different types of rifts.  And then, there are dungeons, which are a whole different ballgame.

Graphics - I think the game looks great.  Some places look better than others, but overall, I've always thought this was one of the nicer looking MMO's.  It's aged a bit, but still looks pretty good.  The environments and attention to detail really help the game last and not get old too fast.  I don't think the screenshots do the game justice.  It looks a lot better in action.  I think the graphics are great.  So long as you don't go in expecting Crysis 3 looking graphics, you will likely be pleasantly surprised at how well the game looks, especially if you are coming from something like WoW.

Overall, I've greatly enjoyed the game, I just wish I had more time to get back into it.  Check out some of my screenshots if you want to see some that are better than those in the preview up above.  This game is a great MMO.  If you are burned out on MMO's, it's not going to re-invigorate you, but once you get into it, it is a little different and has some interesting moments.

reviewText:
Listen to me very carefully before you think all im going to do is praise this game just because i give it a thumb up. This game has a lot of faults, yet at the same time it does a lot of things correctly as well. Not specific enough? Well lets get specific.

The good things? It is fun, the grind isn't bad at all - you can literally get to level 50 in 1-2 weeks without even noticing it - and still get good gear provided you know what you're doing. (If you pvp, do warfronts, and you'll get plenty of pvp gear.) PVP is very accessible - it doesn't require you get the best gear on the right away. PvE is very fun as well, and is diverse provided you're progressing at a good rate.

Now comes the bad stuff. For me this game got old really fast at level 49. I didnt bother to do quests because, well, i was already outleveling them because i was pvping. (Although you could de-level by mentoring and do them to get a 'challenge.')  Additionally, this game is not rewarding. The loot is terrible most of the time - and if you're pvping you'll never ever use it simply because you'll probably have enough 'favor' (ingame currency) to buy better rift store gear, and as another addition, the auction house is locked down until you've managed to either shell out five bucks, or get a rift-exchange in order to get 1500 credits.

Now the AH and pvp doesnt make the game. There's a lot i didn't see, and a lot i didn't get to do. Among more pros, the classes are diverse, and you can play more than one role, making switching 'easy-as-pie' if you want to try something else. But for me, the game got repetetive, and in the end, despite the innovations, still reeked of the deriviative mmo-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t most ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes tend to smell of nowadays anyway. Not much new. However, still gets a 'recommended' simply because its enjoyable.

To sum it up.

PROS
Good and diverse classes. Easy to play multiple roles.
Diverse PvE content.
PvP can be fun, and is easy to get into.
Something i did not mention - Professions are enjoyable.
The grind is barely noticable. (Until 50-60)

CONS
Loot is a joke, and the rift store reflects on this, making this game absolutely unsatsifying in some instances.
Gets repeteive.
AH is locked for selling (You can still buy.) down unless you shell out 5 bucks, or save a bunch of ingame currency to buy a rift exchange. (rex)

Overall, good mmo, but has its fallbacks.

reviewText:
I feel like this game has a ton of potential. Its got great graphics for those with the computer for it but no middle man for those who play on the lesser.

Why I say this is because when starting up a new game, any gamers first instinct is to go into the settings to allow maximum advantage of the cames aesthetics and play. When I personally went through RIFTs settings I first put them as high as possible and it was lovely albeit, still not as fancy as guild wars2; above par for being f2p.

The problem is when lowering the elements it was difficult keeping each portion on a level that would run with a lower end computer without having to pull some farther down than others, thus giving the game not so very fluent appeal.

Another issue with the settings were key-bindings. It was a bit constricting since the game itself is supposed to be modded for player appeal.

All around the game itself is fun in a slower pace but still well-rounded and would completely recommend for those looking to pass the time until ESO:TU. :)

reviewText:
This game is pretty awesome. It has many pros, and few cons.

First, the fact that any piece of hardware can run it is nice, and even the highest-end PCs get a kick out of the best settings. There are many little things to get sidetracked with, from special events to higher level bosses. If you're anything like me, you'll appreciate the chance to show off on a special boss, or one of the many raids. But the best part for myself were the classes.

You choose a side, a race, and one of four basic classes. Depending on the class you choose, from the cleric, the warrior, the wizard, and the (rogue?), you then choose what type of class you are. You could be a rogue tank if you wanted, with no regards to stereotypes, although it definitely changes the playstyle. All of it helps to define you, and determine your soul trees. You can change them later, but the soul trees help to really define you. I'll add that even though most of the abilities seem overpowered in most games, they scale well in this one. Enemies and players have very notable differences in their power between levels. Most MMOs give you the ability to fight enemies many levels higher than you if you're skilled enough. Not this one. Walking near enemies who are even 2 or 3 levels higher spells death for a solo or duo party.

As with anything, there are cons. First, scaling is extreme. You can't expect to compete with people 10 levels higher, and enemies that high are out of the question for the casual adventurer. Second, and probably the only thing that made me stop playing, is the quest system. The quests are very repetitive, and if they aren't, the likelihood is that you're running for 10 minutes to where you need to go. Lastly, the story/lore is very long. If you don't like reading, this game is NOT for you. Most quests are on average several pages long of information you don't need unless you want lore.

tl;dr
Pros:
Very optimized for any hardware, many events to partake in, and lots of character development.

Cons:
Extreme scaling of enemies and players and very repetitive and semi-boring quests.

Give it a try. You can't lose much other than time and memory with this.

reviewText:
I feel like this game has a ton of potential. Its got great graphics for those with the computer for it but no middle man for those who play on the lesser.

Why I say this is because when starting up a new game, any gamers first instinct is to go into the settings to allow maximum advantage of the cames aesthetics and play. When I personally went through RIFTs settings I first put them as high as possible and it was lovely albeit, still not as fancy as guild wars2; above par for being f2p.

The problem is when lowering the elements it was difficult keeping each portion on a level that would run with a lower end computer without having to pull some farther down than others, thus giving the game not so very fluent appeal.

Another issue with the settings were key-bindings. It was a bit constricting since the game itself is supposed to be modded for player appeal.

All around the game itself is fun in a slower pace but still well-rounded and would completely recommend for those looking to pass the time until ESO:TU. :)

reviewText:
This game is pretty awesome. It has many pros, and few cons.

First, the fact that any piece of hardware can run it is nice, and even the highest-end PCs get a kick out of the best settings. There are many little things to get sidetracked with, from special events to higher level bosses. If you're anything like me, you'll appreciate the chance to show off on a special boss, or one of the many raids. But the best part for myself were the classes.

You choose a side, a race, and one of four basic classes. Depending on the class you choose, from the cleric, the warrior, the wizard, and the (rogue?), you then choose what type of class you are. You could be a rogue tank if you wanted, with no regards to stereotypes, although it definitely changes the playstyle. All of it helps to define you, and determine your soul trees. You can change them later, but the soul trees help to really define you. I'll add that even though most of the abilities seem overpowered in most games, they scale well in this one. Enemies and players have very notable differences in their power between levels. Most MMOs give you the ability to fight enemies many levels higher than you if you're skilled enough. Not this one. Walking near enemies who are even 2 or 3 levels higher spells death for a solo or duo party.

As with anything, there are cons. First, scaling is extreme. You can't expect to compete with people 10 levels higher, and enemies that high are out of the question for the casual adventurer. Second, and probably the only thing that made me stop playing, is the quest system. The quests are very repetitive, and if they aren't, the likelihood is that you're running for 10 minutes to where you need to go. Lastly, the story/lore is very long. If you don't like reading, this game is NOT for you. Most quests are on average several pages long of information you don't need unless you want lore.

tl;dr
Pros:
Very optimized for any hardware, many events to partake in, and lots of character development.

Cons:
Extreme scaling of enemies and players and very repetitive and semi-boring quests.

Give it a try. You can't lose much other than time and memory with this.

reviewText:
Very good free-to-play mmorpg.

While I haven't devoted as much time to RIFT as  I have other mmos, it's one that I keep coming back to.  In my opinion, it's the best f2p mmo on the market, and provides a lot of what I expect from a traditional EQ-style mmo.

As a casual player of this title, it seems like there is always something fun to do, and the game makes it very easy to hop into group content (the Instant Adventure feature is particularly great for this). The customizeable player housing is also a major highlight.

I'd recommend this to people who are looking for a free WoW / FFXIV alternative.

reviewText:
One of the better MMORPG's out on the market currently with undoubtedly the best Free-2-play systems available. You don't need to spend any money to unlock zones, or quests. You can hit level cap without ANY hinderence. Unlike other f2p MMO's they tend to penalize the experience gain, well in Rift everyone earns 100% but subscribers earn even more experience!

Rift has a very rich PvE experience, Such as:

- A very fleshed out end-game raiding. Multiple 10 and 20 man raids that vary in difficulty and tiers, whether in organized guild runs or Pugs in general chat.
- Plenty of dungeons to run with expert mode(heroic) which allows for greater challenge and better loot and badges/emblems/tokens to redeem for epics.
- Chronicles, which are single or 2 player story-based instances that drops blues/epics that may be slightly weaker or on par with expert dungeon gear - they are usually pretty quick and can be done once daily to help gear along with dungeons for pre-raiding.
- Huge open world content! Giant boss battles that dwarf whatever Guild Wars 2 dynamic event bosses have to offer, As well as huge rifts in which potentially several raids participate in.

Pros:
- A very classic/BC WoW feel. Very good class building and talent/skill system.
- Player housing! Be as creative as you can be! Crazy things can be done here, albeit not as indepth as Everquest II.
- Casual and Hardcore friendly. Enjoy exploring the world, doing quests, collecting mini-pets and mounts, and searching for artifacts across the world, collecting titles and achievements, also items for your house! There's also plenty of things to grind for the super hardcore players.

Cons:
- The grind can get tedious if you're not used to the older style of World of Warcraft, however It's still easier than some of the more hardcore old school MMO's.
- Auction house is not usable unless you have spent at least 5 dollars in-game OR have bought the game or subscribed for at least one month.
- PvP is kind of lacking, very basic WoW-style battlegrounds is all you're going to get here. PvP ranks are also very long to grind.
- While most of the game is completely free, you are not able to play the expansion souls" (classes technically) without buying them seperately or owning Storm Legion. They can be bought in-game for around 20 dollars and it includes 4 souls (classes) Not entirely necessary
date: but definitely useful to own end-game raiding when multiple roles are needed.\n\nOverall it's a great MMO
recommended: especially for older WoW veterans and newer MMO players a like. Very accessible but also has a lot of depth in terms of class building and skills.\n\nSubscription can also be bought with in-game gold
hoursPlayed: although it will be very difficult for newer players
voteText:
if you manage to hit level cap and do a bit of farming you'll be able to afford it without too much of an issue.


It's free! Give it a shot

reviewText: This game is as FREE as you want it to be. I had played WOW for years and felt like if I wasn't playing in all my downtime I was throwing my money away on it. I tried out DDO and do love that game for the content, however DDO did not have the game flow and player interaction that I had got used to in playing WOW. Finaly with RIFT you have the ability to move thru areas of the game fluidly and have easy interaction with other players. The Soul Tree gives you an interesting way to make your character unique. The rift incounters/invasions are awsome and allow you to form huge open raid groups easily. There is a real money store to buy from, mostly for cosmetic items and unique mounts and such, and you earn rewards thru the loyalty program. I would recomend spending the $5US to unlock full use of auctionhouse. Patron membership is $15 per month, which is close to what it costs for most pay-to-play games. However the game is totaly playable including endgame content without paying. I really do recommend checking this game out.

reviewText: One of the better free to play MMOs that there is, probably because it didn't start that way.  There's some interesting dynamics and things I don't care for.  The fact that each class has the ability to be dps, tank or healer is convenient but the fact that each one can switch their spec on the fly makes building a dynamic group difficult because everyone can do everything... so you are not needed.  They will constantly change skills and trees in an attempt to balance, but they overdo it to the point where you have trouble keeping up with the changes and sometimes ruin what you had.  Like most MMOs these days, top level and end game has a huge gap, to the point where you feel like you're a level one fighting a top level when you face off against a top geared player.  Lastly, the constant paid DLCs result in paying even more money than if this game weren't f2p... $355 for all of it?  This game has a lot of fun stuff but not worth getting attached to.

reviewText:
'There was once a lone wonderer in RIFT. His name was Tangociss. He dished out justice wherever he went, slaying bandits and killing mobs. With his allies on Skype and in his guild, he would adventure throughout Telera and bring justice to the poor NPCs who would offer him quests. He would avenge the poor corpses of NPCs with quests that they gave and the like. Tangociss was a fine fellow indeed, recruiting members into his guild that he formed with his buddies Gisten, BorisPower, Snatmia and Vrush. Tangociss adventured around, closing Rifts and collecting artefacts while gaining repuatation towards the different factions. With his pet and mount, they were hardly ever still in a town, always out in the world adventuring..'

- Extract taken from the offical mind of Tangociss Furrociss himself: 15:43 22/08/2014 ©

If you maged to read the story, then yes, you get to do all the stuff I mentioned. You close Rifts for loot and the like, form guilds, adventure around and the like. Trust me, it is indeed a good game.

Just so ya know, play it with some buddies so ya don't get bored. As for class wise, there are 4 of 'em. Warrior Cleric, Mage and Rouge. There are some rather nice sub-classes within the actual class, so if you choosse warrior, you can be a warlord, or beastmaster (apologies if I mispelt the names) depending on yer playstyle. There are 2 main factions, the Guardians and the Defiansts. Depending on the faction you choose, the starting location and tutorials area will be different along with quests and NPCs you will encounter, but gameplay wise it will still be the same. As for pets and mounts, you use coins (in game currency) which are silver, gold and platnium. You can also buy credits for real money but it is used mainly for cosmetic items. To buy pets, you can buy 'em with loot gained from turning in artefact sets or use credits. You can get a mount in the 2 factions main citys. The mounts range from horses to pandas to even Hellbugs. Quite fun indeed. If all this sounds enjoyable, go ahead and give this game a go. Oh yeah, our guild is recruiting. Doesn't matter what faction yer in, we take any and all members, if you wanna join us, give this guild 'Righteous Alliance' a look in the guild finder, and just say ya read this review or whatever, so I can invite ya in.

Happy adventuring my friends!

reviewText:
summery:
is this game pay to win or pay to play? no
can u get everything in game without paying money? yes
can u get equipment from the store?yes, but equipment that is mostly useless
is game dead? in old world zones it may look so but once u get to 60-65, no
do i need dlcs? trion doesnt know the real defenation of DLC(downloadable content) anything called dlc is actually either vanity items or things u can buy in game
++++++++++++++
p2p,p2w:
recently there has been changes to patron system which brings up the question wheter the game is p2w/p2p, the answer is no, while some of the perks that made the game a bit easier are gone and are patron only now u can play the game without spending a single penny, in fact u can buy patron in game , u just need to farm a bit, im not talking about heavy grinding but spend 1h a day in game trying to make plat(money) either by collecting mats or by soloing old instances and u will be able to collect enough currency though u might jnot want to spend them on patron early on cause there are other important things like soul packs and earrings to spend them on.
well if u consider paying for unlocking some basic things in game like earrrings(that u wont even need before level 65 and then u can easily farm enough plat to get them) p2p, then u r wrong, i havent played GW2 personally but from what ive heard u need to spend money to enter some of the zones and in fact u need to pay in order to level up past some point, now thats called p2p, meanwhile in rift u can access everything and even buy them in game(except for a few vanity items)
though i will be honest i hate the fact that u need to spend credit on boxes in order to get some of the cooler mounts, i rly hate that
buying equipment:
well u can get all the equipment in game and the equipment that u can buy is not as good as the gear dropped from the bosses of the same tier,and u can also buy them with in game currencies,but they are only usefull for filling slots, but hey thats not the point,
point is the current raid standard is T3 but you can only buy T2 with credit and u need to spend in game currency in order to get T3, another nice thing to point out is, there is only 10~15% bonus currency for patrons or the guys that are using boosts, u cant get more than that for the current max tier

raiding:
in order to raid u need achivment, is what some ppl think
if u dont have achivments fear not, just look for progression raids, there are many guilds/groups that want to give raids a try but dont have enough ppl, u can always join them, or alternativly  u can join a guild.
there are many perks for joining a guild like bonus currency and your guildmates(depending on the guild u joined) probably wont mind helping u gear up and might even craft u stuff and most of them dont mind helping u with getting into raids.

PVP:
can be a pain but can be fun at the same time, there are maps for 10to 20 ppl and unlike moba games u r not a hero, if u think u can just go in and kill enemy u r mistaken,yes u might be able to single a few of them out but if u act reclessly u r dead,healing and support are way more important than they are in moba games, and given class system in this game(soul tree) u dont know what u r facing, someone might have enough health to be a tank but might be a tank/healer hybrid
so does gear mean u r awsome? well i,as a mage, have been killed by too many lower geared assaasins and have also killed many guys that out gear me, i would say the way u play your calss/soul is more important than gears,though due to nerfs some of the souls might not be a good choice for pvp nowadays, like warlock(r.i.p)

why do i love this game(pros):
+wardrobe: well u can run around naked as a tank and be immortal, or u can wear heavy plate as a rogue
+soul system: unlike other games u can switch between healer,tank,support or damage dealer at a moments notice(well at least wwhen u r not fighting) and can do them all with any calling(mage,cleric, warrior and rogue) that u r using, of course each of them is unique in its own way, mage healers need to actually attack their enemies to heal their friends and they can summon undead as a necromancer while rogues have to sumon beasts
+macros:dont have enough fingers for pushing all thoes buttons? use a macro, u can find them on net or easily make them yourself
+dynamic world
+crafting
+community
+dimensions: well i got lost in alabiranth that our guild master made and took 2h to finish it and then my senpai said that i have only found one ending and i haven found the real ending plus the bonus, spent 1~2 hours more to find the hidden content and damn they were hidden well, u have to give this whole dimension thing a try
cons:
-well as a non patron u can only quene for random warfronts(pvp maps) and dungeons,though u can ask a friend who is a patron to help u with them
-sometimes u wont be able to understand what the quest or story is about
-mounts in boxes, i hate thoes

reviewText: Was a great MMORPG before it went F2P, then things kind of just went downhill.  I'm not saying that because I'm some bitter P2P guy who just hates all the F2P gamers.  The community really did drastically change when the game went F2P, especially in the lower levels.   It can be a bit frustrating at times rolling a new character.  The chat spam is ultimately what turned me away from the game.  No matter what you do, you can't keep up with it.  You're nearly constantly spammed.  I have spent quite a few of my sessions ignoring spammers a lot more than what I should have to.\n\nAlbeit, this was all around 6 months ago, so maybe things have cleared up.  This was an amazing game in it's prime - easily beating out every other MMORPG I have ever played.  But, sadly, I just can't recommend it anymore, which is sad because I made some great friends and had great times in RIFT....

reviewText:
Downloaded the game and clicked launch.
Glyph launches and asks me to reset my password.
Run through the password reset page on Glyph only to receive another email notification asking me to update some security information on my account.
Log in again, reset my password again, set up some security questions and answers, prove I'm not a Robot by entering the CAPTCHA text and click ok.

Launch Rift again, Glyph opens up, type my new password in and the web based launch page is blank.
Close Glyph, close Steam, relaunch Steam and relaunch Glyph.
Log in again and find 'RIFT - Play Now'.
Receive an error stating 'Your local files cannot be upgraded to the current version. A full re-download is required. Do you want to continue?'

No.

reviewText:
It's WoW without the subscription.

Some content is locked and waiting for your credit card details but the devs gotta make money so don't them for it. The locked content won't subtract from the gameplay, i dare say it actually gives you a bit of a challenge. (except your backpack size, that ♥♥♥♥ is crazy small.) It doesn't do the best job of showing you your objective but an hour in and you'll get use to it.

Combat is fun and simple, there are world events that help with the XP grind. There is also some form of shared looting so you won't have to que at bosses waiting for your turn to get item #1556841.

Don't expect to have an intense story unless your into reading, instead grab a friend and make up your own. It's more fun that way.

Bottom line: It's a free to play MMO, what more can I say about it. Download it, play for a couple of hours, if you don't like it then you uninstall it. If you do like it, throw some money at it, grab some DLCs and get back into the fight.

reviewText:
RIFT is a GREAT free-to-play MMORPG comparable to World of Warcraft but with several advantages, like many more classes (known as Souls) and of course the lack of subscription.

RIFT is clunky in some areas such as animations and hotbar bloating, but most of these issues are minor nuisances rather than a game breaker.

reviewText: This is a great MMO. If you are not questing, you are fighting to close Rifts with easily joinable public raid groups. If you’re not closing Rifts, you are fighting pitch-battles against Rift armies trying to get a foothold in the world. If you are not fighting Rift armies you are fighting against Rift force fortresses that have been constructed by unchecked armies that emerged from unchecked Rifts. The world actually changes and progresses in response to player action or inaction. Love it! The crafting system is amazing, the professions keep you busy and the graphics are fantastic. Seriously, no other MMO has ever kept me so engaged for so long.\nI just took out Patron Status (I am now a subscriber) and a game needs to be very good for me to do that. Also, it’s quite cheap and flexible. A month costs less than $12AU. Really worth checking out. Head and shoulders above other MMOs and I have played many. Oh, and it’s finished. Yep, it’s a working game in which I have been forced to endure 0 (zero) bugs. I am still trying to finish the first FlashPoint in Star Wars Old Republic due to an end mission crash more than a year after trying the game and here is a fully tested and functional MMO. This game is what professionalism is all about. The Help Desk got back to me regarding an account question (my fault) in less than two hours, the community is amazingly helpful and the game is just plain fun. Get this game. Get it now. :)

reviewText:
This game is very good. It has a certain charm about it, with its Warcraft-esque elements and exploration. The customization is in-depth, giving each race/class its own space.

The controls are easy to understand out but hard to get used to. With both the A and D keys and the right mouse button controlling pan/look direction, it feels awkward at first when you need to figure out which one to use.

The game is beautiful, but if you're expecting high-quality graphics, don't get your hopes up; The textures are a little basic, but everything looks bearable.
