reviewText: An impressive game to say the least, the game is polished and easy to get into and start playing...even though it may be a hotkey MMORPG it still delivers the action and fun of any other game, possibly one of the only MMORPG's I have gotten into and stuck too...the graphics are extremely beautiful when playing on Ultra settings and the combat is fun and fast paced although a little complicated and hard to control at times, also I had a problem where I cant use the steam wallet to buy credits...this is a minor issue and im not sure if it applies to anyone else, but overall a fun exicting game well worth checking out, the fact it is F2P makes it even better.  Id rate this a solid 9.5/10 even though some combat elements did let it down.

reviewText:
What rift did right

Rift when it first came out made WoW fans angry saying its a rip of of wow, And at the base it is but it works in its favor. This is a List of what Rift did right that WoW should of done or did.

1. Basing/Ripping off WoW: This might seem like the games bigest weakness but instead its also its greatist thing. They looked at wow and said this work the way the classes are set up and the 2 sides fighting wow fighting a bigger evil. They made this its base, It at the core WoW. but theres more then just that

2. improved Graphics: I know this is simple but the game looks good.

3. Charter Creation: The Charter Cration makes wow look like ♥♥♥♥, It only needs more races. You can really customize a charter. And there are a lot of class options that break down from 4 simpler classes. And also custom armor, sy you have really good armor but you think it looks ugly, you can put other armor on top of it so you look cool but still kick ♥♥♥.

3. less over sextualzing women. Instead of less covered up better armor its the other way (atleast from what I seen) at the start your like in a bikini, but as you play more it covers you more still keeping you sexy.

4. F2P. ever wonder what WoW would be like F2P this is it, just like wow only no meber ship and the DLC is optional like wow. Member Ship is optional though for bonuses.

Keep in Mind Am reviewing this game only from a few hours of game play because it I was really enjoy my self am sure theres more to come. (sorry no spell check) well see you all next time on my next game review!

reviewText:
Rift called by many a WoW clone is (regardless if it's true or not) a great game. Great F2P Model, good gameplay, goo story and overall very engaging.

Like all MMORPGs you start off with a specific combat type, however, unlike many other MMORPG this combat type is highly dynamic offering you countless types of classes.

You are set in a world interacting with multiple worlds, in the sense that the world where you do your regular actions is frequently invaded by planar creatures, creating a good atmosphere where regular global events to fend off attackers take place. These events are called rifts  (tears in the fabric of your universe).

I'm still in the beginning of this game so I will update this review as I progress through it, but so far I'd highly recommend this game for its fair model, and hell, it's free. Give it a shot!

If you are a fan of MMORPG you won't regret downloading it!

8.5/10

Enjoy the Dimensions aspect where you can Build your own Safe Haven where others can visit and see, loads of variety in items to use and manipulate to make it as you want.

Will say this only downfall i see in it as from this point is as a F2P Player you can not Create AUCTIONS, although doesnt look like you have to spend much to gain that ability just a bit annoying.

reviewText:
Edit: I'm not quite sure who the target market for this game is. MOBAs in general have much more lively and balanced pvp matches. And they are f2p as well. Raiding in general is a laggy low-fps jerkfest. My hardware isn't the top of the line, but it handled GTA5 at a decent detail level and framerate. Maybe people who like terrain puzzles and hunting artifacts? Maybe that's the real target market of this game still? Maybe the 5mans? Except that you'll be waiting for a 5man queue to pop maybe once an hour? The scintillating general chat?

Edit: The other thing that annoys me is how the expac souls are engineered to be so much better than the vanilla souls, so that you'll be forced to buy and play the new soul packs. So, if you are say, a mage, you will be forced to play harbinger, whether you want to or not, just because it does the required amount of dps needed to pass the content. Just one example of how f2p ruins a game over time. Another gripe would be how pvp rarely ever feels balanced, where almost every match feels like you're stomping the other team or you're getting stomped on. It's rare you see comebacks or even close scores at the end. It wouldn't matter except that they merged pvp and pve gear together, so that any change in pvp now affects pve, and if there's one thing pvp is always lobbying for, it's change, change, change.

Edit: The thing that really annoys me about this game is the lag. I'm sure that other MMOs do trickery to mask the underlying network latency, and perhaps Trion should look into that. That and the annoying little bugs related to the UI and display that have been in the game since launch. Their QA isn't nearly up to the level that Blizzard's is. And instead of fixing the bugs, Trion seems more interested in rolling out game after game after game. With probably the same sort of bugs in them too.

Edit: Not really pay to win, unless you're willing to shell out $100s. I'm guessing like all freemium models, they're relying on a few big whales to fund the playtime for everyone else. The current level cap 5man experts are decently hard. I can see where they tried to require teamwork, but all it has really done is make the tank shoulder an unequal burden in a PUG. Hence, players willing to tank are rather rare and you will be sitting in an expert queue for quite a while. The entry level raids are also decently hard too and do require even more teamwork to pull off. All in all, if you refrain from being a whale, it's a decent amount of content for not much money. PvP is rather laggy, if you ask me. I asked other people whether this sort of lag was normal and they said yes. So if you like crisp clear PvP, be prepared to be a little bit disappointed.


I played this game when it first came out. At the time, it was quite challenging, the 5man experts required quite a bit of teamwork to pull off properly. I left it when it was still hard, and still a subscription game, mainly because the internet I had sucked at the time. Can't really heal when you're lagging 5000ms. Not really fun either.

I decided to revisit it again, seeing as it's now f2p and subscriptionless, just to see what it's like these days. Everything is now easy mode, you're only in danger of dying if you get out of range of the healer. Otherwise the mobs just die in front of you and give you that sweet XP. The world is also ridiculously easy too, they've set the aggro radius on most mobs to be quite small, it's fairly easy to saunter in somewhere, hit a quest and then saunter back out.

I'm disturbed by the fact that you can now buy purple gear at the level cap. It may be a tier behind and the current tier you may have to play for, but it looks a lot like pay to win. I've no objection to paying for things, and in some ways, f2p makes for a nicer experience. Because nobody's on the clock (either you or the game designers) you don't feel that urgent need to zip through the levels to get to the cap, so you can get on with raiding. And the game designers (who you're really playing against) don't feel that need to slow you down, so they can get more money out of you. Time is money. You want to move fast, they want you to move slow.

But paying to win goes a bit too far. I haven't reached 65 yet (only 55 now), so we'll see.

Everybody (if you're willing to pay for it) can now do every role. Mages, can literally tank. Yes literally. The mage tank is no longer a joke. Warriors, can heal. No, not with bandages. They really can heal.

But if you just want something to kill time with, and all you care about is questing and 5mans, there's a lot of free content they're just giving away. Even if all you do is just dps with one of the original soul combos, it'll probably take you at least a month to get to 65. And then you can just move on to something else :P

reviewText:
Ignore what people are saying about pay-to-win here. BiS gear is still only avalible through Raiding and PvP progression and will stay like that.

As of this review the game has entered it's second expansion and this will be based off of 3000+ hours of gametime since I have stopped playing RIFT through steam.

First and foremost, RIFT offers an insane amount of customizability compared to other MMOs on the Market. There are the four basic classes, Clerics, Mages, Rogues and Warriors. Each of these classes can perform EVERY major role (tanking, healing, support and DPS). As a warning though, in order to get every role avalible for every class, you need to purchase two packs that launched with their respective expansions (so unless you pay for the expack souls, mages can't tank, warriors can't heal, rogues can't heal, clerics can't support). Aside from this howewer, the game is still very functional and you can still fill a majority of roles with the exception of one. Another interesting feature is that you can mix and match souls (specs) together to make unique playstyles to suit how you want to play the game.

Second, RIFT offers some entertaining large scale zone events. You could be wandering around in one of the game's leveling zones collecting items, completing quests, etc and suddenly you get a notice on your screen that something is going on in the zone. 2 minutes later dimensional portals (Rifts) open up and start spewing out mobs into your leveling zone and player areas. At this time it is tasked to the players to close those Rifts and go ham on the raid boss that had the bad luck to be leading the invasion. These events provide both a fun way to level and boast a wide variety of objectives, thereby keeping the game fresh.

Third, RIFT features excellent graphics compared to other MMOs (as long as you're not playing on a toaster). RIFT is a game that both plays good and looks good. Character models look good, the enviorments look great and the fantasy world is a prime example of how you design an MMO. Telara feels alive and this is one of the things that keeps me hooked to RIFT.

In regards to the combat, it plays like WoW, but RIFT's customization allows for consistent changes to the flow of combat.

In essence, if you're looking for a MMO to play or have yet to try one, I'd recommend RIFT.

reviewText:
I came back into the game after a long break, had all classes level 65,  T1 raid gear on all, ready to try to get back into it.
First expert dungeon, got kicked by some very busy guys because of my dps (rusty on the rotations and all, but sill good for an expert).
Ok. Trying some PvP. nearly one shoted by a pyromancer, the numbers on the health bars and on the dps meter are kinda depressing. Very well. I start to remember why i left this game.
Checking my currencies, my reputations and stuff, i realize that im going for the same old repetitive frustrating grind if i stay. ok. Alt F4.

Then, i reopen the game, log in on a lvl 35 rogue, and start queing for some pvp. I have always found low level pvp extremely fun, mostly because once you understand what build and what stuff is godlike at certain levels, then you just walk on the maps slaughtering anyone who did not, and have some cool fights against more prepared people.
So i wait 30 minutes, get into a match. Ok 20/2 cool will be fun. Queue for another wait 7 hours (really 7 hours), alt f4 another time, unistalling the game this time. Bye rift.

reviewText:
This game is very good. It has a certain charm about it, with its Warcraft-esque elements and exploration. The customization is in-depth, giving each race/class its own space.

The controls are easy to understand out but hard to get used to. With both the A and D keys and the right mouse button controlling pan/look direction, it feels awkward at first when you need to figure out which one to use.

The game is beautiful, but if you're expecting high-quality graphics, don't get your hopes up; The textures are a little basic, but everything looks bearable.

reviewText:
Edit: I'm not quite sure who the target market for this game is. MOBAs in general have much more lively and balanced pvp matches. And they are f2p as well. Raiding in general is a laggy low-fps jerkfest. My hardware isn't the top of the line, but it handled GTA5 at a decent detail level and framerate. Maybe people who like terrain puzzles and hunting artifacts? Maybe that's the real target market of this game still? Maybe the 5mans? Except that you'll be waiting for a 5man queue to pop maybe once an hour? The scintillating general chat?

Edit: The other thing that annoys me is how the expac souls are engineered to be so much better than the vanilla souls, so that you'll be forced to buy and play the new soul packs. So, if you are say, a mage, you will be forced to play harbinger, whether you want to or not, just because it does the required amount of dps needed to pass the content. Just one example of how f2p ruins a game over time. Another gripe would be how pvp rarely ever feels balanced, where almost every match feels like you're stomping the other team or you're getting stomped on. It's rare you see comebacks or even close scores at the end. It wouldn't matter except that they merged pvp and pve gear together, so that any change in pvp now affects pve, and if there's one thing pvp is always lobbying for, it's change, change, change.

Edit: The thing that really annoys me about this game is the lag. I'm sure that other MMOs do trickery to mask the underlying network latency, and perhaps Trion should look into that. That and the annoying little bugs related to the UI and display that have been in the game since launch. Their QA isn't nearly up to the level that Blizzard's is. And instead of fixing the bugs, Trion seems more interested in rolling out game after game after game. With probably the same sort of bugs in them too.

Edit: Not really pay to win, unless you're willing to shell out $100s. I'm guessing like all freemium models, they're relying on a few big whales to fund the playtime for everyone else. The current level cap 5man experts are decently hard. I can see where they tried to require teamwork, but all it has really done is make the tank shoulder an unequal burden in a PUG. Hence, players willing to tank are rather rare and you will be sitting in an expert queue for quite a while. The entry level raids are also decently hard too and do require even more teamwork to pull off. All in all, if you refrain from being a whale, it's a decent amount of content for not much money. PvP is rather laggy, if you ask me. I asked other people whether this sort of lag was normal and they said yes. So if you like crisp clear PvP, be prepared to be a little bit disappointed.


I played this game when it first came out. At the time, it was quite challenging, the 5man experts required quite a bit of teamwork to pull off properly. I left it when it was still hard, and still a subscription game, mainly because the internet I had sucked at the time. Can't really heal when you're lagging 5000ms. Not really fun either.

I decided to revisit it again, seeing as it's now f2p and subscriptionless, just to see what it's like these days. Everything is now easy mode, you're only in danger of dying if you get out of range of the healer. Otherwise the mobs just die in front of you and give you that sweet XP. The world is also ridiculously easy too, they've set the aggro radius on most mobs to be quite small, it's fairly easy to saunter in somewhere, hit a quest and then saunter back out.

I'm disturbed by the fact that you can now buy purple gear at the level cap. It may be a tier behind and the current tier you may have to play for, but it looks a lot like pay to win. I've no objection to paying for things, and in some ways, f2p makes for a nicer experience. Because nobody's on the clock (either you or the game designers) you don't feel that urgent need to zip through the levels to get to the cap, so you can get on with raiding. And the game designers (who you're really playing against) don't feel that need to slow you down, so they can get more money out of you. Time is money. You want to move fast, they want you to move slow.

But paying to win goes a bit too far. I haven't reached 65 yet (only 55 now), so we'll see.

Everybody (if you're willing to pay for it) can now do every role. Mages, can literally tank. Yes literally. The mage tank is no longer a joke. Warriors, can heal. No, not with bandages. They really can heal.

But if you just want something to kill time with, and all you care about is questing and 5mans, there's a lot of free content they're just giving away. Even if all you do is just dps with one of the original soul combos, it'll probably take you at least a month to get to 65. And then you can just move on to something else :P

reviewText:
Edit: I'm not quite sure who the target market for this game is. MOBAs in general have much more lively and balanced pvp matches. And they are f2p as well. Raiding in general is a laggy low-fps jerkfest. My hardware isn't the top of the line, but it handled GTA5 at a decent detail level and framerate. Maybe people who like terrain puzzles and hunting artifacts? Maybe that's the real target market of this game still? Maybe the 5mans? Except that you'll be waiting for a 5man queue to pop maybe once an hour? The scintillating general chat?

Edit: The other thing that annoys me is how the expac souls are engineered to be so much better than the vanilla souls, so that you'll be forced to buy and play the new soul packs. So, if you are say, a mage, you will be forced to play harbinger, whether you want to or not, just because it does the required amount of dps needed to pass the content. Just one example of how f2p ruins a game over time. Another gripe would be how pvp rarely ever feels balanced, where almost every match feels like you're stomping the other team or you're getting stomped on. It's rare you see comebacks or even close scores at the end. It wouldn't matter except that they merged pvp and pve gear together, so that any change in pvp now affects pve, and if there's one thing pvp is always lobbying for, it's change, change, change.

Edit: The thing that really annoys me about this game is the lag. I'm sure that other MMOs do trickery to mask the underlying network latency, and perhaps Trion should look into that. That and the annoying little bugs related to the UI and display that have been in the game since launch. Their QA isn't nearly up to the level that Blizzard's is. And instead of fixing the bugs, Trion seems more interested in rolling out game after game after game. With probably the same sort of bugs in them too.

Edit: Not really pay to win, unless you're willing to shell out $100s. I'm guessing like all freemium models, they're relying on a few big whales to fund the playtime for everyone else. The current level cap 5man experts are decently hard. I can see where they tried to require teamwork, but all it has really done is make the tank shoulder an unequal burden in a PUG. Hence, players willing to tank are rather rare and you will be sitting in an expert queue for quite a while. The entry level raids are also decently hard too and do require even more teamwork to pull off. All in all, if you refrain from being a whale, it's a decent amount of content for not much money. PvP is rather laggy, if you ask me. I asked other people whether this sort of lag was normal and they said yes. So if you like crisp clear PvP, be prepared to be a little bit disappointed.


I played this game when it first came out. At the time, it was quite challenging, the 5man experts required quite a bit of teamwork to pull off properly. I left it when it was still hard, and still a subscription game, mainly because the internet I had sucked at the time. Can't really heal when you're lagging 5000ms. Not really fun either.

I decided to revisit it again, seeing as it's now f2p and subscriptionless, just to see what it's like these days. Everything is now easy mode, you're only in danger of dying if you get out of range of the healer. Otherwise the mobs just die in front of you and give you that sweet XP. The world is also ridiculously easy too, they've set the aggro radius on most mobs to be quite small, it's fairly easy to saunter in somewhere, hit a quest and then saunter back out.

I'm disturbed by the fact that you can now buy purple gear at the level cap. It may be a tier behind and the current tier you may have to play for, but it looks a lot like pay to win. I've no objection to paying for things, and in some ways, f2p makes for a nicer experience. Because nobody's on the clock (either you or the game designers) you don't feel that urgent need to zip through the levels to get to the cap, so you can get on with raiding. And the game designers (who you're really playing against) don't feel that need to slow you down, so they can get more money out of you. Time is money. You want to move fast, they want you to move slow.

But paying to win goes a bit too far. I haven't reached 65 yet (only 55 now), so we'll see.

Everybody (if you're willing to pay for it) can now do every role. Mages, can literally tank. Yes literally. The mage tank is no longer a joke. Warriors, can heal. No, not with bandages. They really can heal.

But if you just want something to kill time with, and all you care about is questing and 5mans, there's a lot of free content they're just giving away. Even if all you do is just dps with one of the original soul combos, it'll probably take you at least a month to get to 65. And then you can just move on to something else :P

reviewText: This is a pretty good MMO. It's free, but I would totally pay money to have it. There are a few microtransactions in it, but they aren't necessary to have fun in the game. They're actually pretty pointless, but I guess they have to make money some how.\n\nThe basis of this game is all about rifts (how the title of the game originated). There are MMO-typical quests throughout, but there are also rifts which are tears into other dimensions. These rifts produce monsters, and you must fight them off to seal the rift. There are many types of rifts, from fire to water to earth to air, and many others I didn't mention. Several mobs appear which you have to fight off (sometimes alone, sometimes with friends). There are different stages within a rift. The higher stage you get to, the harder the mobs become to kill. When a rift is finally sealed, you get rewards. Most importantly, you get planarite (how much you get depends on the stage you reach). Planarite can be used to buy planar goods, which can help you with battling more rifts or by improving your armor to make you more OP. So far, I've only gotten to level 21 or 22, but I can tell that I will be playing this for a long time.

reviewText:
I came back into the game after a long break, had all classes level 65,  T1 raid gear on all, ready to try to get back into it.
First expert dungeon, got kicked by some very busy guys because of my dps (rusty on the rotations and all, but sill good for an expert).
Ok. Trying some PvP. nearly one shoted by a pyromancer, the numbers on the health bars and on the dps meter are kinda depressing. Very well. I start to remember why i left this game.
Checking my currencies, my reputations and stuff, i realize that im going for the same old repetitive frustrating grind if i stay. ok. Alt F4.

Then, i reopen the game, log in on a lvl 35 rogue, and start queing for some pvp. I have always found low level pvp extremely fun, mostly because once you understand what build and what stuff is godlike at certain levels, then you just walk on the maps slaughtering anyone who did not, and have some cool fights against more prepared people.
So i wait 30 minutes, get into a match. Ok 20/2 cool will be fun. Queue for another wait 7 hours (really 7 hours), alt f4 another time, unistalling the game this time. Bye rift.

reviewText:
Recommended to download and play from the RIFT website...

Pros;

+ Very large explorable world

+ Character Classes (Mage, Cleric, Ranger, Warrior)

+ Professions (Fishing, Mining, Crafting, Smithing, Butchering, Foraging, Cooking...)

+ Quests (Profession based, Collecting, Killing, Delivering..)

+ Mountable Pets - (Horses, Camels, Tourtousies, etc...)

+ Player Versus Player

+ Play Solo or Party with others

+ Dungeons + Raids

+ Rift portals - (Essentially random openable enemy portals with waves of enemies, reward/diffictulty dependant on rift level)

+ Build a house - Buy a pre designed house/plot and add furniture, walls, ceilings or objects.

+ NPC Merchants

+ Swim Underwater

+ Playable using mostly a keyboard

+ Great to play with a friends

+ Switch Server at any time

+ Good account security measures


-Microtransactions are available however totally choice based decision and not necesary, some have purchased all their
gear with money only to get bored of the game (probably).

-Contrary to other reviews you do not need all the DLC to access other areas or level up quicker.


Cons;

- Buggy on Steam... use the >> Glyph client << to download and play
- Somewhat difficult to grasp some of the mechanics at first
- Servers are spread over 6 servers making cities feel not so city like with about 10-30 people in a city, possibly making high level gear trading difficult?
- To unlock additional item slots/pouches you will need dlc, not too much of a problem tbh.

reviewText:
One of the few games I can keep coming back to, which makes it one of the better MMO's out there.

There is so much freedom, character creation wise, you can either go with a pre-made skill tree, or you can put one together yourself, I've found myself to do this more frequently, not one character I make is the same, ever, this keeps it interesting, not to mention I can unlock more if I ever find the desire to spend the money to unlock it with, not yet though, there's still much to explore without spending a dime!
I've spent about 10 Euro as I'm writing this, and compared to a lot of the games I've played, time/money ratio is excellent,¨(I am an extremely patient player, so this may vary from person to person) So even if this is a F2P game now, don't be afraid of spending a little cash, unlike some games, what  you buy stays with you, so you don't get screwed over and feel like you're being punished with a demo" once you quit paying. I'm looking at you

reviewText: I have really enjoyed my time with this game! I know that I don't have many hours, but I think that this game is better than most people think! The game itself is similar to WoW and other MMOs but Rift is the only F2P MMO that I know of that isn't pay to win. Lots of people complain that it takes too long to grind for items and levels, but that's the point of an MMO. It wouldn't be fun if you were automatically level 100 with tons of overpowered items, the game would get boring fast.\n\nAll in all, if you're looking for a fun MMO to play with friends that you don't have to pay copious amounts of money to play, then Rift is your game!

reviewText:
This game is truly amazing, takes a while to get into the good ♥♥♥♥ in the game. When you get out of one of the 2 faction spawns (Guardians or Defiants). This game INCOURAGES exploring the world, they have fetch quests but its not as bad as some other MMORPGS. They give you the quest, you finish it and go to a different person, some long distances some small. The skill tree is really good, could use a bit more in my oppinion but decent. The community is very friendly, invite people to guilds so they can help them if they have questions or even be very kind and give you a free mount or such. I was lvl 20-25 (cant remember) but you get a 60% speed increase when on the mount, people in my guild were talking about that mount which is 25plat which is quite a bit for a lvl 20-25 and i said that its very hard to get one, one of the guildies/guild member brought me that mount to be very very kind and they were a high ranking player. PVP is truly amazing and takes alot of skill and time, the most annoying thing in pvp for me is getting your faction swapped to the enemy team to balance it out which is a good thing but you want to be with your faction, either way its fun. The game has a wardrobe feature meaning if you have a piece of armor or something you can but it in your wardrobe slot for example, Helm and it goes into your wardrobe slot and it gives the look but not the stats. Microtransactions are okay... i guess, you dont HAVE to buy them for the game to be good, they are just things like if you play a mage you get 3 BASE things to choose from, example stormcaller, warlock ect and the Microtransactions give you a couple of new ones that dont make a HUGE difference. The Map is ♥♥♥♥ING HUGE and each zone like Gloamwood, Silverwood and every other one has their own secret stash like thing, if you open it you get ramdom armor of your class that rounds down to every 5 LEVELS, if you are lvl 20 you will get a lvl 20 item. If you are lvl17 you will get a lvl 15 item. Puzzles are great, they require teamwork like pressing several buttons that open a globe that your break and has a key in it, then it spawns a chest with a dirty bag, the same thing like the secret stashes like i said previously.

I would rate this game 7.5/10 but i do recommend this game if you love MMORPGS
Cons:
The start of the game is very very boring and you need to be about lvl 15 for ♥♥♥♥ to kick off.
Can be very annoying to get the kind of gear you want but its an MMORPG sooo......
Microtransactions are ehhh, would be better without it but.....
Wish there was gliders and boats like Archeage but mounts are good enough.

Pros:
Friendly community
Character creation is very very good.
Fun game after lvl 15
Great PVP
Wardrobe
Huge map
Great secret treasures
Great puzzles that require teamwork to complete

reviewText:
This game is incredibly fun, has great graphics, beautiful scenery, mobs, etc.
This is for a fact, not a pay to win game! You can obtain real money currency (gems) with your ingame currency by buying gems off the auction house from other players. I absolutely love this since most MMO's are P2W.
This game is better than Guild Wars 2, World of Warcraft, and several other mmos. If you don't believe me then try it out yourself!
There are 4 main classes and 37 subclasses which are insanely good. Different  skills you can learn, such as Fishing, Outfitting, Butchering and several more!
As the name suggests, there are things call Rifts" around the world you play on. These rifts start out as a tear which can  either turn into a large or small rift. It's basically an event to fight waves of  enemies
recommended: and bonus waves for loot. However if a rift is left alone
hoursPlayed: it sends forces out across the  world and takes over areas of the map. A rift lasts 99 minutes  though
voteText: so it won't completely destroy the world.\nAll in  all I love this game and plan on playing it for a very long time!"

votesHelpful: true

reviewText:
I have somehow managed to put 200+ hours into this game, and I regret almost all of it.

Pros
-Instant Adventures are pretty fun.
-Sidekicking is a great feature.
-The idea of rifts are cool.
-Really customizable UI.

Cons
-Combat is incredibly boring.
-Animations suck.
-PVP is insanely unbalanced.
-Microtransactions.
-Leveling is unfathomably boring.
-It seems as though there is nothing to do in the world.
-Only one starting zone for Guardian and Defiants, instead of race starting zones.
-Race design is crap.
-World Events are boring.
-Female dwarves don't have beards.

A good 25% of the cons are nitpicks, but if these types of things bug you, as they bug me, it's definitely not the game for you. Other than that the game is somewhat decent for being free.

reviewText:
Don't follow the steam play time record. I've been playing it longer then I've been using steam... With that said.

I bought the collector’s edition the second week after the game came out and even then I couldn’t find it much fun.

At the time I had a lower end PC that was perfect for Raiding in WOW Cataclysm but wasn’t strong enough to walk in town in Rift. But that was all on my end and became something I was able to fix. And yet, the game even after a major hardware upgrade the game still feels poor and had a bit of lag (60MB download speed and 5mb upload).
The games bread and butter are the open world rift events which was OMFGITHINKIPOOPEDMYSELF fun at the time, but now the feature became a normal thing in most major mmo RPGs (Like running over people in car’s in games like GTA). I found raiding and dungeon crawling lacking real team work just like WOW (I.E. Heroic mode) Where if you admit that it’s your first time running the raid or dungeon you will get kicked… But, if you do get to stay in your going to have a hard time in figuring out WTSF you are doing and how to keep up with the pack, if they know how to run it.
PVP-      Step 1. ) Roll a Bard class
Step 2.) Place both hands on the opposite side of your keyboard
Step 3.) ???
Step 4.) In a down and up motion proceed to smash your face on all the keys
Step 5.) Victory!
Overall- Even in 2015 the game is not fun, I found Starwars/GW2 and watching CSPAN a better use of my time even at max level.

reviewText: While I don't recommend this game, that's not to say that I think it's a bad game. I don't recommend anyone who has ever played World of Warcraft play this game due to the simple fact that this is a huge ripoff of the far superior WoW. The developers of this game made it much harder by over-complicating the skill tree and adding microtransactions under every rock, bush and tree in the game. Want the best items? What? Work for them? No, no no. Just make it easier on everyone and give us 5.99 and we'll call it a deal. Besides the extreme presence of microtransactions and the over complicated perk/skilling system, this game isn't bad for it being free. However, just be prepared for *ALOT* of kill x and collect y quests and spending alot of time trying to figure out the perk system. But hey, the game is free and if you're into playing a ripoff of WoW without having to pay, this is the game for you!

reviewText: I'm not rating this game down because I don't like it. In fact, I love this game. In the few hours I have played I have found out it is a total WoW killer in both Gameplay and Graphics. I am not reccommending this game because of the horrible launcher you need to use, Glyph. It causes more problems than it needs to. Took me over an hour just to get my profile to register on the launcher and after that I got to enjoy the bliss of this game. But then as soon as a new update comes out the launcher updates the game and then breaks. Validated the game files, even done a total re-install, and nothing. This launcher is one of the worst I have used in all my years of gaming. I reccommend the game but for the launcher and all the problems I have had with it, I just cant give it an up-vote. If you're willing to put up with the problems that the launcher gives then I highly recommend this game for any MMORPG fan.

reviewText:
Well as you may can see, I have played this game for about 1500 hours (300 pre Steam) and about 1200 hours on the Steam Version and for the most time, was this as far as I saw it the best MMORPG in the world, but something has changed.
And this something is like most time when talking about a game that went free to play, the business model and the community.

I will start with the business model:
It sucks!
And the community... no seriously this game is way too greedy now. You know that something is wrong when you pay 100€ for a mount and some useless stuff: https://rift.trionworlds.com/products/view-product?code=PRIMALIST_COMPLETE_GLYPH&flow=spotlight-tags&request_locale=en_US and that was not all; You want new souls? 40€ please, you want a new class? 40€ please and so on.
And even this is not all, because there are souls, equipment slots and classes locked behind a pay wall it's also fair to consider this game as pay to win...

And the community is also more falling into a free to play pit... I do not have to say more to this because things like this are always some kind of subjective and not objective to see

But you can always try it yourself if you want since this game is free to p(l)ay

reviewText:
First I'll say that rift is a great game, however it has one small flaw which decided whether or not I would recommend this game to others.

The game itself is as good I would say as any subscribtion f2p MMORPG out there, better then some actually because the game is actively worked on by devs and lots of bug fixes, I almost never have had a game crash or see visual bugs. The game is clearly a polished and honed mmorpg and is pretty good at its current state effective of 6/13/2014.

However, the small flaw, which actually is a huge deal for me personally, made me decide to not recommend and quit the game entirely.

This game is free to play in name only, You are not required to, but pretty much have to if you are going to play anywhere past level 50, meaning endgame. And what would be the point of investing time and energy into a game where you hit a pay wall. the pay wall in rift is its loyalty points issue. basically, in rift, you cannot auction. at all. not one item. unless you have spent 10 dollars. and their is a in game currency coin cap. 2500 platinum which is an extremely small amount when people are running around with tens of thousands of platinum.

All in all this game is good and i would say probably would suit casual players, but even then the no auction and coin cap rule is foolish IMO on the part of rifts dev team. The rift community is quite tiny and probably not growing due to this one small/large issue depending on how you look at it. But this is the games pay to play wall. Beware.

reviewText:
I want to say this game is good.  Though I have to be honest I dont know if it is.  A while back i was invited to test this game....and didnt due to lack of time.  It came out so now i decided to give it a try.  The first thing i noticed is that this game is on a free to play model now with a subscription if you want one.  Thats neat...and i suppose some people hate it or like it.  Anywise I downloaded the game and was immediately given the ability to log into the game with an account or as a guest.  I decided to reclaim my old account to do this.  Anywise....i started up the game and was immediately told about a patch and how i could play but had to wait for downloading in game...since the big patch was big.

So i went into the game....and decided to make a character.  A few deceptions became evident.  First off 6 races....there is only 3 per side....you have to choose a side...with each race simply being an analog of the others...with slight changes to looks and some slight different abilities they can get.  Already with this mechanic i can see this game is going to be full of issues and other weirdness.

You dont make a game requiring you to play sides...sorry thats an automatic going to make the game lame function.....but maybe i can slog through anywise.
So i made a character.....noticed the graphics for some of my choices had not loaded yet.....ok warning sign two.....the red flags with this issue are evident....those pictures should have been loaded a while back but where not....means bad optimization and probably bad other things......if they are too lazy to fix something like that which is a simple fix...then they are probably too lazy for much story or fun gameplay.....ok goign to try to slog through that as well.

So i start the game and get a...failed to connect to server and black screen,
Been like this for over 15 minutes.......i have a black screen with what i assume is a waiting load icon.

At this point with these issues like this......i can say maybe this game is fun....but these red flags show....a huge amount of issues.....if they have this sort of thing happening.....the game is probably fairly bad.

but i am going to slog through or try too.....

even though this rating says recommend.....i may alter it.....if i can ever play this game.

Ok I finaly got into the game....graphicwise it isnt bad...both sides start with similar quests.
Flow of the game is typical.....but i can see this is definately is a cash shop game....lots of things locked requiring unlocks and a plethora of things to buy in the cash shop.  Control wise its typical has a power bar....which you can flip pages on and you can add power bars which is a huge plus.

Only draw back for powers is this game uses the archaic and idiot global cool downs.  As in you use one attack and 5 of your other attacks are cooling down....in the real world someone isnt going to stand around waiting so many seconds to use a differing manuever....unrealistic....and annoying.
But onthe plus side you can have many powers and use many power bars.

You can change your focus of abilities as well...as long as you have not spent souls on powers in a focus....and unfortunatly some of the focus' seam to duplicate each other....only the names and some graphics are different for skills.

So the supposed many focus things is a bogus lie....but then it does add to the concept of tailor making your character.

I find myself disapointed with this game....with those features in those ways....but i will slog through to see what the rest of the game offers.

Ok so following the main storyline...we find we get cutscenes....and a very disjointed storyline.  Storyline is the world you are on has these rifts to other worlds opening and wreaking havoc....possibly this is due to a war with gods.
Each faction side player is a resurrected hero....one side represents some holy divine group .while the other group wants to protect it a different way.  Looking at costumes and things I believe its a matter of one uses technology while the other uses magic.....storywise its not very clear why they are against each other or what the division truly is....as you can see on the side that supposedly uses magic...totems and things are actualy constructs from technology items.

At a certain point you fight bad guys who you get told have come from rifts....but for whatever reason at a ceratin point you get sent back in time...to prevent the war and fix the world....not sure why this is done....because the point you get sent too...is just as hosed as the place in time you left....go figure on the logic.

Anywise while running around you will get the usual quests and missions...and also run into rifts that open giving further mini-quests.

The cash shop can provide you with everything.....so in essence you can use it for pay to win....yet.....why would you bother when you can most everything in game.
There are the usual a few cash shop things you can only get from there...and there is a subscription mechanic you can still use.

I have played an assassin like character for a bit now....and after slogging through many things found that indeed the stealth isnt just a buff....as you eventualy can turn it on and off and not have to turn it off....only problem i am having now is deciding where my soul points go....as i dont know my maximum points...so i have to be kind of stingy in what i get.

Now i mentioned focuses for each of the 4 class types....it looks like each character can get 3....now the reason you might take duplicating focus types....ie...ones that are similar is for the extra bonus power up you get to fight or do things.

For me right now i looked at the premade focus packages...and chose one...but decide to fit my assassin better i wanted to be able to not only have assassin skills but teleporting and better fighting.  So i altered my focuses to assassin, riftwalker, and blade dancer.....there is no package that uses these three...so i named my build ninja.  I feel strong kind of.....as an assassin strike does not one shot kill....but the ability to eventualy be invisible for as long as I like is a must have for me.

ANywise i am digressing in to things you should find out for yourself.

Perhaps others will like it or maybe they will hate it.....I do not think this is a bad game....so i recommend this title for those who want something different.  But its not enough different from other games to warrent a huge amount of time to play it to figure out if you like it or not.

It is free to play...so far i am playing free....dont know what i am missing for not being a subscriber....but maybe i will find out later.

7/10

The following are comming from an exped mmo player with so many hours spent on WoW that blizz would almost give me a phd - up until cataclysm
Warning :Rift is similar to wow but it is only superior to the amount of mounts and the fact that it is free. if you are to give as much money- or more- as you did in WoW then go back to WoW since mechanics are superior and it has a bigger playerbase.
So good things in general
-  Although few classes, there are so many specializations that are actually counting for different classes if you really think about it
- 20 man raiding
- Constant World Events
- Up to 65(current max level) it isn't pay to win*
- teleporting and not ♥♥♥♥ing gryphon travelling for half an hour to reach destination
- It is possible to pick up more than 3 professions being a jack of all trades
- Tactics even at early dungeons are somewhat interesting and not just tank n spank
- With a great sum of in game money you can buy credits *
- Good Community but not great.
Bad things
- Paying users can get to lvl 65 (max lvl) and max their professions in less than half time than the non paying user
- Earrings - although only two slots - are locked unless you gather like 100k of a single currency or pay real money/credits and are somewhat vital parts due to massive stats
- Some items are restricted to the ones that have dlcs" (namely: Planewalker Water) also costing 100K or real money/credits
- TOO MANY CURRENCY TYPES

that are NOT needed
- Quests and lore are borderline uninteresting
- Bagslots also locked unless you spend credits/money
- Trinkets

reviewText:
Overall I have played many MMO's mainly for the PvP. Ive played played RIFT in BETA and for the first year of its release. Revisiting this game recently as it went F2P I wanted to see what has changed and if the PvP was competitive. The game has no open-world pvp, I couldnt find anyone to fight other than lvl 65's which as a lvl 28 mage would have been suicide to engage. So I was left to que for warfronts that did pop fairly regularly.

The class balance in the game is terrible, a decently geared bard will never die. Add to the pay to win store that pretty much means you either smash the other team or you get obliterated. Good, fun, close, tough matches are unicorn rare.
For me the game is a terrible choice if you like PvP, if you like PvE I am the wrong person to ask.

Product received for free

My honest review of this game!
Pros:
-The game is interesting to play
-Has the regular" MMORPG classes and roles
-Has 3 continents on the map
-Has some quests that I have never seen before in a game
-Has a Minion mechanic which I've never came across in a MMO before

PvP (with several gamemodes)

-World Events Every now and then

Cons:
-Some features are paid
-Have to pay to have 2+ characters
-DLCs
-Have to pay to unlock the "Auction House"
-Some of the quests are really boring
-Have to grind for ages to be able to purchase gear if You don't want to pay real money

I recommend this game because its awEsome and really fun! Especially if You play with a group of friends"

reviewText:
Don't look at my steam play time, I've been playing since Open Beta 2, and I have to say, no MMO comes close to touching this one!

As a veteran WoW player who was part of many world and server firsts, the whole cookie cutter spec got stale, as did paying a monthly fee. While I had to pay a fee each month to play this, it was soon found that there are hundreds of talent tree combinations that are all viable for everything! It's amazing, and it really shows how much care Trion put into this game. I specialized and generalized and each had its merits in the grand scale of the game.

The world is also huge. There is never downtime, unless you make downtime by going into a city and standing there. I was questing once when I was a low level and a rift opened  right above me. As I was fighting for my life, another rift opened up a few meters away. Then, both rift's creatures started fighting eachother, it was amazing how alive the world feels!

Finally, the community is amazing. People who are jerks or trolls get black listed by everybody, so they can no longer progress. This means that people don't do those things and everyone is super helpful. Even endgame grindy quests are made fun and easy with good partners.

Basically, if you like WoW, or if you want to try a new MMO, play Rift. With the money you save from subscription fees, you can put it to supporting Trion through their store, and the community and world will ensure that you have a good time.

reviewText: Don't want to be rude, but this game is boring. I tried to persevere and get further in game. I had a feeling like I was playing unsuccessful version of World of Warcraft. Story is so uninteresting, graphics really lame (I switched from medium setting to maximmum and there was no change, I swear) and animation of the cinematics so shoddy. Even gameplay and interface remains me MMO's of last decade.\n\nSorry to fans, but I really can't recommend it.

reviewText:
*I have played more hours than my game log shows*

Tremendously dated gameplay and graphics. Combat moves at the speed of cold molasses, even by MMORPG standards. As an avid gamer, I found this game painful.

On the bright side, the pacing would be great if you are stuck on a DSL connection. And there are some cool game mechanics, but other MMORPG's have done them much better...
